Ottawa, August 14th, 1936.

Right Reverend Sir,

The Department has carefully considered your letter of the 17th ultimo, requesting new batteries for the Joussard Indian Residential School.

It is noted that you request two sets of 56 cells, or a total of 112 cells, similar to those supplied to the Grouard Indian Residential School last January. The cost of these batteries amounted to $1,319.00.

While certain funds were provided for expenditures at the Joussard Indian Residential School this year, the Department understands that you have already made arrangements to expend the money provided.

Recently, we have been obliged to incur some very heavy expenditures at other residential schools for which no special provision was available; consequently, the amount in this year's appropriation for unforeseen expenses has been practically all assigned.

Under these circumstances, the Department finds it extremely difficult to see its way clear to supply batteries to the Joussard School at an approximate cost of $1,300. Would it be possible to make the present batteries last for another year or, failing this, would one set of 56 cells be sufficient for this year and a similar set could be supplied next year.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Yours truly,

Rt. Rev. Joseph Guy, O.M.I.,
Bishop of Grouard,
Grouard, Alta.

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Mr Harold McGill M.D.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I am in receipt of a letter from the Department dated August 14th in the matter of Batteries for Jousard Indian Residential School.

The request is made if actual Batteries can go over Winter. I am sorry to say that this very day the Principal came here for the very purpose of telling me that their light was red due to the fact that the Batteries were exhausted. He entreated me to write without delay. The suggestion was made to take this year a single set of Batteries, viz 56 and next year another 56 could be added. I regret to say that the Engineer from Bruce Robinson Limited who supplied the Batteries in Grouard consider that batteries should be installed immediately and no set added later. In view of that fact, I would suggest the Department to supply one set this year (Iron clad) and I will borrow sufficient money to pay for the other set, said amount to be reimbursed me next year out of 1967-68 appropriation.

I hope my suggestion will prove acceptable and will be treated accordingly.

With anticipated thanks I remain

Yours very truly,

Bishop of Grouard.

Ottawa, September 4, 1936.

Right Reverend Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of Your Lordship's letter, requesting that new batteries be supplied for use at the Jousard Indian Residential School.

In this connection I would say that no funds were specially provided in our Appropriation to cover the cost of supplying batteries for this school. As you are aware, only the sum of $10,000 was provided in our Appropriation for the current fiscal year for equipment, general repairs, etc., at the Indian Residential Schools in your diocese. Accounts have already been received and paid for a large part of the appropriation, and, no doubt, you will have further accounts to forward, which would utilize the whole amount provided.

The matter of supplying batteries has received very serious consideration, but, owing to the fact that our Appropriation was so greatly reduced and that our expenditure, to date, for Indian education, is overdrawn, I regret that it will not be possible, this year, to provide the cost of new batteries, either in supplying one set of 56 or two complete sets of 56 cells, each.

The Department will be unable to guarantee, should you arrange for the purchase, yourself, that you would be reimbursed during the fiscal year 1937-38.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Right Rev. Jos. Guy, O.M.I.,
Bishop of Grouard,
Grouard,
Alta.

January 26th, 1937.

Dear Doctor McGill:

Miss P. Blanchfield, Stenographer at our office, Calgary has forwarded to me here, the following telegram:

Calgary, Alta. Jan. 26th, 1937.

Following received. Agent L'Heureux quote,
Joe Morin aged fifteen orphan pupil in Jossard Residential School has admitted guilt attempt to burn main building stop. No fitting punishment can be given here stop. Recommend three years detention in Father Delmas School stop. Please wire at once if authorized. Message ends.

Resi. I do not recommend sending Joe Morin to the Duck Lake School, which is not a fireproof building. I consider a boy that age, having such bad tendencies will be a bad influence amongst the pupils there. Moreover the Duck Lake School is filled and there is a waiting list of young children to be admitted from local reserves.

I consider Joe Morin's act punishable under the Criminal Code. However, if his age does not permit prosecution under this code, he should be dealt with under the Juvenile Delinquents Act for the Province of Alberta.

In conversation with the Rev. Father P.P. Moulin, Principal of the Ermineskin Residential School, here, whom I met Sunday last, he informed me that his Excellency Rev. Bishop J.Guy of Grouard was now in Ottawa.

I mention this thinking that perhaps you may wish to discuss this matter with him.

I am answering Agent L'Heureux telling him that the matter is being referred to the Department, who will instruct him, what action to take.

I should be pleased to have a copy of the Department's instructions to Mr. L'Heureux for my information and file.

Your obedient servant,

C. P. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Director,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

CANADA
The Joussard Indian Residential School was the object of an attempt to destroy it by fire by one of the pupils on the 24th. At 3:00 P.M. Jos. Morin, aged 15 and orphan, placed birch bark and kindlings within the wall of the West Porch, behind an electric three-knife open switch and put a match to the bark; two or three other boys were watching him. They all scattered after the bark was ignited, Morin going to the dairy barn to help the men milking the cows. One of the others went by the front entrance and gained entrance to the sisters' store-room and stole an assortment of candies.

The fire was discovered by the sister Assistant-Superior who ran promptly to the main switch to cut off the electric current and returned to extinguish the blaze with basins of water obtained from the near-by laundry. A chemical extinguisher was also used, its spray being directed inside the partition. The damages were negligible and were confined to a flame-scorched wall in the porch.

For some time the cause of the blaze was assessed to a defective electric switch. But after the supper the sisters had found some evidence that this fire was the work of a pupil and that it was premeditated. For instance one girl declared that a boy told her a few days before that he had the idea that the school would burn "Wednesday or Thursday but not later than Sunday" and asked how they (the girls) would like this opportunity to go home. He said he had had a dream. It was also found in the girls' dormitory that they had made neat parcels of the toys given them at Christmas and everything did look as if they were making ready to go to their parents and relatives soon; just in the same manner as they prepare for the summer holidays.

Piecing all this together they made a thorough investigation with the assistance of the Principal and soon found out that this fire was started by a criminal hand. The evidence secured led to pupil Jos. Morin as the perpetrator and he readily admitted his guilt.

This boy, Jos. Morin, had been in that school for nine years. The Reverend Principal had in his great confidence. He is of little better than average intelligence and unlike other boys of his age, he had very little liking for play and for sport; during dallying recesses he would invariably go to the principal or to the man in charge of shop or barn work to ask them to give him work. He was helping to the full extent of his ability. In view of his good disposition the Principal had provided him with some woodworking tools and had asked the Engineer to teach him the rudiments of Carpentry and light shop work. The Engineer was eminently satisfied of his progress as well as were all others with whom he came in contact with.

This boy is paid annuity under the late Chief Kinnosayo's t cket No.1 of Driftpile Band. His ancestry is rather obscure. It is thought that he came to be adopted by an Indian family through the Child's Welfare Branch of the Provincial Department of Public Health.
Discussing the question of a fitting punishment for him, with the Principal, Rev. Father Bertrand, we have both agreed that his prosecution under The Juvenile Delinquents Act and sentence for a term in a Reformatory School would serve no useful purpose but rather prepare him and harden him for a criminal life. The agreement was to ask Mr. Inspector Schmidt's authority to transfer the boy to a distant residential school (the Duck Lake Indian Residential School being recommended) following a good strapping administered before the other pupils by a Constable of the R.C.M.P. to make the example a salutary one.

Mr. Inspector Schmidt having advised that he had referred the case to the Department, I received in due course a telegram from the Director stating his interview with His Lordship Bishop Guy and advising that prosecution should be made under the Juvenile Delinquents Act. As little or no information were given with my original request for transfer, I have taken the liberty to postpone the trial until the case can be further reviewed and if it is the wish of the Director, he may re-affirm his decision or give new instructions for the settlement of the above case.

In the meantime the boy, Morin, is under detention at the agency.

Yours faithfully,

N. P. L'Heureux.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 22nd February, 1937.

Dear Sir,

I have to refer to your report of the 6th February and particularly to the case of the pupil, Joe Morin, a boy of fifteen years who set fire to the Joussard Indian Residential School, and note your suggestion that a good strapping administered to this boy by a Constable of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police before the other pupils would be a salutary example.

In reply I have to say that while that may be true, there is no legal authority for that treatment for such an offence and the Department might be severely criticised for authorizing such a course if something unusual should occur in connection with the proceeding. It is thought that this boy should be proceeded against under the Juvenile Delinquents Act in the regular way.

Director of Indian Affairs.

N.P. L'Heureux, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Driftpile, Alta.
Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 22nd instant, your file No. 75-131, in connection with the prosecution of pupil Joe Morin under the Juvenile Delinquents Act.

I regret that the legal aspect of my proposal of a good stumping does not permit it to be carried out.

I am taking immediate steps to have the boy tried before Mr. Magistrate Stewart and expect this to be done on the 3rd proximo.

Yours faithfully,

N. P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

Dr. H. W. McGill, Esq.,
Director of Indian Affairs,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.
Lesser Slave Lake Agency,
Driftpile, March 4, 1937.

Report for February, 1937.

The boy Joe Morin, accused of attempt to burn the Joussard Indian Residential School, has been brought to the Agency to be detained there until his trial. Divisional Inspector Radcliffe of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police has informed me that trial would take place as soon as Police Magistrate Stewart receives from the Attorney-General the required commission to try a juvenile under the Juvenile Delinquents Act.

H.P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

I must admit I prefer to be at a distance to remit the enclosed labour returns after the reception my other accounts have received, not from you, but from some other quarters. You will recollect that in my requests for estimates I had included an item for $2000.00 to reimburse us for work on Barn at Joussard (outside of the equipment), $1500.00 had been voted for a 75'x 36' combination cow barn and horse stable. You will admit that amount was not sufficient. The enclosed returns show the complete outlay for wages. You will note that there is only one sheet. The foremen did not think of having the other two signed by the men, a fact which was noticed only when he handed in the returns. Rev. Fr. Serreand Q.M.I., the Principal at St. Bruno's School, to whom I remitted the borrowed money, was not conversant with the fact that duplicate and triplicate copies had to be signed. I suppose you can have proper copies made and certified. Our foremen has left for Wabasca and will not be available (nor specially will be the men) for a few months.

As already suggested please keep this and other accounts until you are satisfied that they are entirely turned down and then...there will be still hope!!!

Dear Sir:

I have, for acknowledgment, your letter of August 9th, in which you refer to certain expenditures made in connection with repairs and improvements at the Jeussard, Grouard and Wabasca R. C. Indian Residential Schools, under authority of Order-in-Council 18/1886 of July 24th, 1886.

I may state that the above mentioned schools are three of those operated under the jurisdiction and direction of the Right Reverend Joseph Guy, O.M.I., of Grouard, Alberta. It would appear that it has been the practice of the Department in the past to deal with the schools under the direction of Bishop Guy, for administrative purposes, as a unit.

The amounts specified for the schools in the Order-in-Council were taken from reports received from Bishop Guy at the time the Estimates were in course of preparation. Bishop Guy, however, who later visited Ottawa and discussed these expenditures with the officials, pointed out that the inaccessibility of the schools, his failure to obtain satisfactory transportation facilities, in addition to the difficulty experienced in providing proper supervision for the work of construction, made it impossible for him to proceed with the repairs in conformity with the terms of the Order-in-Council. Inasmuch as these schools had been in the past considered as a unit, Bishop Guy was permitted to proceed with his programme of repairs and improvements.

Monsieur:

Dernièrement nous recevions une lettre circulaire attirant l'attention des Principaux sur le danger de feu. L'on nous demandait de nous mettre en relation avec le Département, si nous désirions quelque chose en ce qui concerne la protection contre le feu.

Ici notre école a seulement sept extincteurs, ce qui n'est pas suffisant; car ils sont très espacés. Il me semble que nous devrions en avoir cinq ou six de plus, qui pourraient être placés à différentes places de chaque étage, et qu'on aurait immédiatement sous la main en cas d'incendie, ce qui permettrait d'éteindre le feu immédiatement.

En conséquence je serais très reconnaissant au Département s'il voulait nous envoyer les extincteurs désirés.

Recevez mes salutations respectueuses,

Père Paul Serrand

Your reference: 606

Division of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

Recently, we received a circular letter drawing the attention of the Principals to the danger of fire. We were requested to communicate with the Department in case we needed something in connection with fire prevention.

There are only seven fire extinguishers in our school, which is not enough for they are placed too far apart. It seems to me that we should have five or six more which could be placed on different floors and which would be immediately to hand in case of fire, enabling us to extinguish it without delay. Consequently, it would be greatly appreciated if the Department would forward us the required extinguishers.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) Father Paul P. Serrand,
Principal.

Grouard, Alta., Oct. 29th, 1938.

Mr. Philip Phelan, Welfare & Training Branch,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Under same cover, I am forwarding to the Department the report of the work done at the Joussard School during last summer. I expect to be in position to send the other reports in a short future.

Some buying of material has been done directly. As pointed out in previous correspondence, it was due to the fact that notification of passing through the Department has reached me too late, when most of the material had been delivered. Cement was taken in in April in order to profit by frozen roads in case the season would be wet. I do not insist as the explanations have already been accepted by the Department.

Let me confess openly that refunding within a relative short delay would accommodate me. The paying of the material as well as of the wages through the ordinary revenues has put me short of money. With December will start the buying for Schools which can be reached economically but in winter time, on snow roads.

As foreseen, the crop has been very poor, not to say more. We will have to buy most of the vegetables: onions, carrots, peas, corn, etc. This never happened in the past. It means an heavy burden on all our Schools.

Believe me, Dear Sir,

Yours very truly,

F.S. LaJoie, O.M.T.,

February 20th, 1939.

REPORT on Water Supply Situation at
Joussard Residential School, Alberta.

I inspected the water supply situation at Joussard Residential School on 2nd February 1939 and discussed the matter as fully as possible with all local and interested authorities. Before proceeding on this trip, I discussed the problem with Mr. C. F. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Affairs at Calgary, and also obtained as much information as possible regarding the water levels of Lesser Slave Lake from Mr. O. H. Hoover of the Dominion Water Power Branch, Calgary.

The present water supply installation has worked reasonably well and satisfactorily during the summer seasons in the past, with the exception of certain points which I will bring out later in this report. They have always had trouble, but have managed to operate under difficulties during the winter seasons until this winter owing to the pipe line from the intake to the pump freezing. This is a stretch of 450 feet of 1-1/4" galvanized iron pipe. This winter the lake level has receded lower than at any previously recorded time, with the result that there is no water at the intake and water has to be hauled in barrels from out in the lake to the pump, from whence it is pumped to the buildings.

The school buildings are on a bench about 10 feet above extreme high water mark of the lake. Attempts have been made in the past to drill wells close to the main buildings but no water was found to a depth of 150 feet.

There is a dug well at present about 600 feet from the main building which supplies the barn. This well is 60 feet deep and 5 x 5 feet on the bottom and water seeps in very slowly, sufficient to handle comfortably the requirements for 30 head of stock. The water is hard and unsuitable for domestic use without treatment, which experience is common throughout the Peace River District.

As there are one hundred and fifty people - pupils and staff - resident in the school, with the likelihood of a gradual increase in numbers each year in the future, it is considered that any well in the vicinity of the main buildings would not give sufficient water to supply the needs of the school.
The improbability of finding a well in the vicinity of the main buildings with sufficient and suitable water for domestic and fire protection purposes leaves only one alternative as a source of supply and that is from the main Lesser Slave Lake.

This school is supplied with inside plumbing, water closets, baths and fire hydrant equipment. However, in my opinion, the water storage reservoir and septic tank are quite inadequate for the numbers of children and staff in residence. There is a 440-gallon pressure tank for water storage in the boiler room to which an additional 440-gallon tank should be added. The septic tank is 6' x 6' and too small for 150 people, with the result that the children still use outside dry privies.

Recommendations

The first thing to do would be to dig a well close to the present pump house on the lakeshore. If sufficient and suitable water is found here, the water supply situation will be eased considerably as it can be pumped with the present equipment to the 440-gallon reservoir in the boiler room. The only additional equipment required being another 440-gallon pressure tank.

Estimate of Cost for doing Above Work:

| Item                                      | Cost   |
|-------------------------------------------|--------|
| Digging and cribbing well                 | $100.00|
| 440-gallon pressure tank installed in boiler room | $250.00|
| Alterations to pump connections           | $50.00 |
| Engineering expenses and contingencies    | $50.00 |
| **Total**                                 | **$450.00** |

I was informed that the school authorities had previously dug a well at the pump house but did not get sufficient water for their needs. Their explanation was that the lakebed consists of blue clay through which there is little flow or seepage. However, I think it advisable to try again with another well near the pump house on the lakeshore. If, however, this does not prove satisfactory, the only recourse will be to go out into the lake for it. The lakebed is very flat and it will be necessary to go a long way out into the lake with the intake.

The present intake pipe has 450 feet of 1-1/4" galvanized iron pipe laid on the lake bed. This was covered with several feet of earth and rocks to guard against frost in winter time, but the wave action during storms on the lake practically demolished this covering so that great difficulty and expense has been incurred every winter in countering the effects of frost. Some difficulty was experienced in getting sufficient water at the intake to pump, but until this winter it was always managed. This winter, however,

*********
the level of Lesser Slave Lake has receded lower than at any previously recorded time so that, in order to get to a depth of water sufficiently deep for the intake to be below the ice, it would be necessary to extend the intake a further 950 feet where the water was 4'-8" deep on 2nd February, 1939.

The whole intake pipe, 1400 feet, should be buried in the lakebed below frost line and the problem is how to do this in this isolated locality without suitable equipment.

The most economical method to do the excavating for the trench is by use of a small dragline. From enquiries made while on this inspection trip, I do not believe there is one nearer than Edmonton where the Provincial Government has a 60-tonne 1/8-mile-dragline machine. There is the possibility that a small dragline may be used for the proposed improvements to the water supply system at Sturgeon Lake Residential School (See separate report for Sturgeon Lake); also the provincial Government will most likely be using a small dragline in this district next summer. This being so, I suggest that at the suitable time an arrangement be made with the Provincial Department of Public Works for the loan of the machine when it is in the vicinity, and thereby affect a saving on cost of freighting by dividing it between the provincial government and the jobs at Jouniard and Sturgeon Lake.

If it is found necessary to extend the intake out into the lake, I believe the most suitable time of the year in which to do the work would be last to 15th October when the lake is low and just before freeze-up.

Estimate of Additional Cost if it is found necessary to extend the intake into the Lake from the pumphouse.

| Description                                                                 | Cost   |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------|
| 950 lin.ft. - 2" galvanized iron Pipe                                      | $315.00|
| Excavating trench and backfilling (including an allowance for freighting dragline) | $635.00|
| Taking up and relaying 450 feet 1-1/4" pipe and laying 950 feet 2" pipe     | $100.00|
| Engineering expenses, freighting pipe and contingencies                    | $100.00|
| **Total**                                                                  | $1,050.00|

This cost would be additional to the $450.00 mentioned previously in this report.

As is the case for the other Residential Schools in the Peace River District, I would recommend that any work done on the water system be left to the local authorities under the Indian Affairs Branch, our Engineer's Service remaining in an advisory capacity only. The prevailing rates of pay are little more than half of what we would have to pay under the Dept. of Labour's Fair Wage Scale and it would make it decidedly inconvenient for the local authorities afterwards if we went in there and paid the higher rates for labour.

As the water supply and sewage disposal are closely related problems, I checked over the sanitary arrangements at this school and am forced to say that, while there has been no trouble or complaints in the past, I do not approve of them. There is a 6' x 6' septic tank, which is too small for 150 people and the disposal field is too restricted. This is situated on the bank of an intermittent stream which empties into the lake about 500 feet west of the school pumphouse. Into all the waste water from the laundry and kitchen is dumped directly into this intermittent stream without treatment. As a result of these conditions, I believe there is a danger of contaminating the lake water at the intake and recommend that this situation be brought to the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch to be considered as a separate project during the summer months when the stream is flowing and the examining officer would have the best chance of tracing its discharge.

Assistant Engineer.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Water Supply Situation at Jousserd Indian Residential School

As instructed in your memorandum of January 20th last, arrangements were made for the making of an investigation of the water supply situation at the above school, and report received is attached in duplicate.

By the system now being used at the above school, water is obtained from a well for the stock and from Lesser Slave Lake for domestic use. This system has been partly satisfactory until this winter, except that storage facilities have been insufficient. Owing, however, to extreme low water, in Lesser Slave Lake, there has been no water in the intake this winter.

From history of wells in this district, it is our Engineer's opinion that it is useless trying for water in wells near main building. The only solution, therefore, appears to be to go to the lake for water either by infiltration well at shore or by extending present pipe line further into the lake.

We therefore recommend trying first, a well near lake shore line with estimated cost of $450.00, as detailed on page 2 of our Engineer's report. It will be noted that only $100.00 of this amount is for the well, the remainder being for improvements to present distribution system.

Failing to obtain sufficient water by above method, then it will be necessary to go out into the lake. The present pipe line is 450 feet long. This would have to be taken up and re-laid, below frost line, and an additional 950 feet of pipe put down, making a total of 1,400 feet of pipe line out into the lake.

Our engineer gives an estimate of $1,350.00 for this work but it should be understood that no estimate for this type of work can be guaranteed owing to uncertainty of availability of suitable equipment for the work in this remote district.

All labour costs in the above estimates are based on prevailing rates in the district as referred to in the last paragraph of page 3 of our Engineer's report.

Re: Water supply for Indian schools at Grouard, Fort Vermilion, Sturgeon Lake and Joussard.

We have practically no information about the ground water occurrences near the above mentioned schools, but judging from the geology it seems advisable to limit the depth of drilling in some cases.

The chances of getting a water supply near the Sturgeon Lake School are probably good. The district is underlain by the Wapiti formation which contains several sand horizons that carry a good water supply in the Peace River district. I cannot tell to what depth you will have to drill here but it should be no deeper than the top of the black shale which underlies the Wapiti formation.

The chances are probably poor of getting a supply of good water from the bedrock of all the other schools and drilling should be confined to the surface deposits. The bedrock in these places is a black or dark grey shale.

It is impossible to tell exactly where you should drill, without having seen the ground. Usually in searching for water in the surface deposits, gravel ridges and stream valleys are good places to prospect.

We will be very glad to co-operate with you in any way we can, and if you wish to consult us please do so at any time.

If you drill please let us know what results you get in order that we may have the information on file.

(Sgd.) R.T.D. Wickenden.

Monsieur:

Re: Water question

Je dois vous dire que votre lettre du 27 mai m'a déçu, et je ne puis comprendre comment l'Ingénieur envoyé par le gouvernement ait pu songer à faire creuser un puits ici. L'expérience a été faite et elle est concluante. À l'endroit même où se trouve la pompe, un puits a été creusé, et jamais nous n'avons pu avoir de l'eau du lac. La raison en est que le fond du lac est formé de terre glaise absolument imperméable; donc tout argent dépensé pour un puits sera de l'argent gaspillé.

L'Ingénieur m'a dit que la seule chose à faire était de prendre l'eau du lac, cela au moyen de tuyaux, lesquels tuyaux doivent être enterrés assez profondément pour n'être jamais atteints par la gelée. C'est là le seul moyen de nous assurer l'eau nécessaire à notre école. Tout autre système ne saurait donner satisfaction. J'espère que votre Département voudra bien s'en rendre compte et nous donner l'argent nécessaire pour faire ces travaux, sans faute cette année.

Nous avons dû dépenser au-dessus de 350 piastres pour le transport de l'eau uniquement, l'hiver dernier. Nos finances ne nous permettent pas de recommencer cette expérience. D'autre part je n'ai point besoin d'attirer votre attention sur le danger du feu. Avec le système d'eau que nous avions l'hiver dernier si un incendie se déclarait, nous serions dans l'impossibilité de l'éteindre. Tout disparaîtrait dans les flammes et peut-être aurions-nous à déplorer des pertes de vie. Aussi j'apprécierais hautement que vous fassiez diligence en ce qui concerne cette question.

Veuillez agréer Monsieur l'assurance de ma considération distinguée.

Rev. P. Serrand, O.M.I.,

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re - Joussard Residential School, Water System.

With regard to the above project, you will recall that based on investigations made by one of our engineers late last winter, our memorandum of March 6th last recommended first trying for water along the lake shore by a shallow well. Failing to secure water then the alternative was to go out into the lake. We have received a letter from Mr. Walker reporting findings of Mr. Snelson's investigation when recently at Joussard. From test borings and pits dug by Mr. Snelson in numerous places along the beach above the present water level and within 100 yards of the present pump house no indications of any quantity of water were obtained. In every case heavy impervious blue clay was encountered and continued as far as tests were made namely 30 feet. It is understood that well drillers who have worked in the vicinity report that this clay stratum extends from 80 to 200 feet below the surface. Obviously, the possibility of obtaining water from shallow wells along the lake shore need not be further considered. There, of course, remains the original alternative of running a pipe line far enough out into Lesser Slave Lake to reach a suitable depth of water. For such work Mr. Snelson estimates that the cost would be $1,000.00, providing a small Bear-cat trenching machine now at Jasper could be secured for the work and the work done in weather when ice was about 12 inches thick. If done when the lake is not frozen over, he estimates the cost would be $1,500.00.

As another alternative Mr. Snelson tentatively suggests the drilling of a well at least 200 feet deep near the mission buildings. Such a scheme he estimates would cost $1,000.00.

Mr. Walker in his report however recommends that further work at Joussard be postponed until the results of the well drilling at Grouard is known. He advises that a decision will then be made as to which of the two above methods will produce the most satisfactory water supply.

In the meantime, Mr. Walker recommends that three 720 gallon pressure tanks be purchased immediately and installed in the boiler room at Joussard to store a supply of water for fire protection. His estimate for this is as follows:

| including fittings delivered  |        |

| Total                         | $700.00|

In addition -----

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Water Supply, Joussard Indian Residential School.

October 27, 1939.

In reply to your memorandum of the 24th instant with reference to the above project, we quote a wire received from Mr. Walker this morning as follows:

"Retel water supply Joussard Indian School reports received today from Grouard state well being drilled there now at five hundred feet and testing three to four gallons soft water per minute STOP Would consider this satisfactory STOP No pressure tanks or other material received or work done yet at Joussard STOP Would recommend well be drilled at Joussard instead of deepening intake into lake and that One thousand dollars extra be added to item Two my August nineteenth estimate to allow well being drilled to five hundred feet if necessary This would bring total estimated cost Joussard installation to twenty seven hundred dollars."

It will be noted that Mr. Walker now recommends the drilling of a well at Joussard rather than installing an intake system for obtaining water from the Lake. On this basis, he estimates the total installation at $2,700.00. As you are aware no funds were transferred to this Service for work on this project and it is therefore not known what money is available.

As regards Mr. Walker's reference to pressure tanks, you will recall that in our memorandum of August 29th last, recommendation was made for the purchase of three tanks at a total estimated cost of $700.00. On the 15th ultimo, we supplied specifications for these tanks and our memorandum of the 19th ultimo, in which we advised it would be satisfactory to this Service for the Department to purchase these tanks in any way that they might suit fit, appears to be the last correspondence on our file, and therefore, we have no information as to what action has been taken towards the purchase of the three tanks in question.

Respectfully submitted,

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Joussard Indian Residential School

I am in receipt of your memorandum of October 30 in which you point out that the total amount required for the water system at the above-mentioned school will be $2700.00.

Funds for this purpose are available in our appropriation but it is necessary to secure an Order-in-Council before they can be expended. Application is being made to Council for this purpose and I do not anticipate any difficulty in securing the required approval. Under these circumstances you should have your engineer proceed with the work immediately so that it may be completed before it becomes too late in the season.

In connection with the three 720 gallon tanks recommended in your memorandum of the 15th of September I may say that an order for these was placed with Gorman's Limited, Edmonton, Alta., on October 24 and it was understood that the three tanks would be delivered immediately. Director.
Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Grouard Indian Residential School
    Joussard Indian Residential School
    Vermilion Indian Residential School
    Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School

This week Right Reverend U. Langlois, O.M.I., Bishop of Grouard, visited this Branch and discussed with us the work that is in progress in connection with the water supply system at each of the above-mentioned schools.

As you have previously been informed funds were provided in the current year's appropriation for the improvements suggested by your engineers. However, it appears from the information received from Bishop Langlois that the work has not yet been completed.

No provision is being made in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41 for money required in connection with the water systems at these schools and moreover the Principal of each of the schools is anxious to secure a considerable amount of new equipment if funds available in the current year's appropriation are not being used in connection with the water systems.

The season is advancing and I am extremely anxious to know at the earliest possible date what progress has been made at each of the four schools mentioned above, also when the water systems at these schools will be completed.
I understand from the information contained in memoranda that you have submitted in connection with the above that all the materials required have been purchased.

I trust that you will find it possible to let me have, at the earliest possible date, a complete statement regarding the situation at each of these schools.

Director.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Please find enclosed receipted accounts covering the sum of $1,150.00 forwarded by the Department for the Water System at our Joussard Indian Residential School. I hope that everything will be found in order.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Please find enclosed a requisition for equipment for our Jossard Indian Residential School. I have delayed presenting same as I didn't know up to lately how much money would be requested to complete the water system there. The water found last winter was containing so much iron that it was out of question to use it. The driller was called back and we were lucky enough to strike a good flow of better water around 300 feet. It contains some iron yet, but so little that we are advised to use it. It is a flowing well. Our intention is to build a reservoir to store a certain quantity of water. The pumping to the pressure tanks will be made from this reservoir.

Having found a good flow of dry gas when drilling the well, we have requested the driller to drill a hole for that gas. Unfortunately, there was so little gas left that we have been compelled to abandon the idea of having gas for the kitchen stove and possibly for the furnaces. We had deemed that it was worthwhile to try.

Last winter when I was in Ottawa, you have expressed your intention to visit our Missions during the present summer. I have been expecting you since spring. It is not too late. The summer is rather dry. The roads are in fine shape. It would be a pleasure for us to welcome you in our seminaries. If you decide to come, let it be understood that you will be at home in any of our Missions. Besides bringing us the pleasure of receiving you, a visit would surely interest you. Do your best to come.

Yours very truly,

F. S. Lajoie, O.M.I.,
Grouard, Alta.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

This is to explain my message of yesterday requesting you to have a carload of cement, 500 sacks, shipped to the Joussard Indian Residential School or to give me the authority of ordering same from Canada Cement Co., Calgary.

The analysis of the last water found being considered satisfactory according to the report of the Provincial Analyst, we have deemed advisable to finish the installation without delay. It requires a reservoir to store a quantity of water. The well is flowing at the rate of around four gallons a minute. The building prospected will store the reservoir and the pump.

Besides, the ice-harn having collapsed lately, we have decided to erect a new one in the bank of a creek passing close to the School with cement walls. It is why I have applied for 500 sacks of cement. Cement is far cheaper by carload than by sacks. Local freight rates are prohibitive at the hundred for such material.

Having not received message giving authority to order myself, I have come to the conclusion that you have found possible to have this material ordered right away by the Purchasing Agency. I have been fortunate to secure the services of a very capable man in this line and any delay would compel me to lay him out. It would not be easy to get him back as his services are requested in many places. I expect to hear that the cement is coming any day.

Thanking you for the attention given to this, I remain, Dear Mr. Phelan,

Yours truly,

F. S. Lajoie, O.M.I.,
Grouard, Alta.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

In your letter of Aug. 20th ultimo, you pointed out that there was nothing in the estimates for the purchasing of cement this year for our Joussard School, while there was some money for a refrigerator. You were suggesting that the purchase of the refrigerator be postponed to next year.

Let me point out that due to the difficulty of getting electricity in the country, we have decided not to ask for an electric refrigerator. An ice-barn, rather than a room to store ice, is being erected. We had to do something to keep ice as the old ice-barn collapsed this summer, as pointed out in a previous letter. Some of the cement shipped in August is being used for the new ice storage. The erection of such storage is far less expensive than an electric refrigerator. Besides, the operation of an electric refrigerator with a private electric plant is not practical.

Most of the cement received was used for the building of a water reservoir. As explained formerly, the well at Joussard is a flowing well, but the water has to be stored before being pumped into the pressure tanks. Besides, the water has to rest to allow some gas coming to evaporate.

May I point out that there is an error in the address given to firms supplying what you order for the Joussard School. You give: "Joussard Indian School, Grouard, Alta." It should be: Joussard Indian School, Joussard, Alta." The precise address means the saving.
of transportation on fifteen miles. Joussard Station is only a few miles from the School.

The weather keeps very dry. Brush fire is running. Let us hope that it will keep away from our schools. We have taken out four or five small fires started close to the mission here at Grouard, but it is impossible to fight large fire at miles away in the bush. Rain or snow would be welcomed.

Yours truly,

P. B. Lajoie, O.M.I.

Grouard, Alta., Dec. 2nd, 1940

Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Division,

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Please find enclosed statement for the money spent at the Joussard Residential School for the completion of the water system. A few dollars have been put on an Ice-House which takes the place of an electric Refrigerator prospected last year.

Of the $2,400.00 allotted for improvements and equipment at Joussard, the sum of $482.54 has been applied for desks and beds while a carload of cement has absorbed $408.75 making a total of $892.75. The balance which is $1,507.77 has been spent for material and wages paid as shown by attached vouchers.

The water system at Joussard works perfectly. It is to be hoped that the light trace of iron in the water will not interfere with the operation.

REPORT ON JOUSSARD RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL IN LESSER SLAVE LAKE AGENCY

Buildings:

There has been no change in the number of buildings for some time past.

The present buildings are of frame construction, shingle-roofed, and are very well built and cared for. The whole plant and lay-out is very tidy, and presents a beautiful view from the present highway, which passes along the shores of the lake (Lesser Slave) — approximately three hundred yards North of the buildings. I am told, that since the Alaska Highway construction has started, hundreds of people have been seen to stop and take pictures of the school buildings; there must be thousands of these pictures in the United States.

Fire Escapes:

I cannot do otherwise than repeat what I have said before regarding fire escapes: i.e., These are wooden staircases outside the building. I found them in good condition and repair, but I cannot conscientiously say that I consider them the proper thing on a three-storey, frame building, with the dormitories on the top floor. What would happen if there should be a fire and a panic occurred, no one can say! I have always advocated outside, metal towers or tubes, and have not changed my opinion in this respect. I realize, that at the present time metal fire escapes are very difficult — not to say impossible to get. I was informed that fire drills are held regularly.

A Night Watchman is employed during the Winter months.

C. Pant, Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Alberta Inspectorate.
REPORT ON JOUSSARD RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL IN LESSER SLAVE LAKE AGENCY

Farming Operations:

The School have a small grain farm only. This is being enlarged very slowly, as it has to be hewed out of the bush, which is heavy poplar, and expensive to clear and break. This year they had a fair crop of oats and threshed approximately 900 bushels.

Garden:

They have a beautiful garden, and harvested, among other things, 2,000 pounds of tomatoes. The potato crop was very good and was being taken up while I was there.

Feed:

The School have no hay lands; they buy their hay from the Indians at time of hay-making, in July and August.

C. Pant. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Alberta Inspectorate.

Memorandum to:

Dr. H.W. McGill

Re Purchase of Battery for Joussard Indian Residential School - Your file 131-4-5

I have your memorandum of the 8th instant in reference to the above.

As you are aware the responsibility for the expenditure of the money voted by Parliament for the purchase and maintenance of equipment and repairs to church-owned schools is placed upon the Department and not the churches. The Minister has on many occasions objected to the churches spending the money first without our knowledge or authority and then sending the bills to the Department for payment. I understand you have several times asked them to discontinue this practice and they promised to do so.

We are now being asked to make a very substantial contribution for the purchase of a battery for the Joussard School; the cost of which is $1081.03 although when Council approved of the manner in which monies voted for these purposes were allocated, only $300 was set aside for repairs to the Joussard School. If, therefore, we are to contribute towards the cost of the battery a further Recommendation to Council will have to be made. Whether it would be wise to transfer the amount set aside for repairs to the Vermilion and Wabasca Schools is a matter upon which you will have to reach a decision.

As to the purchase of a battery, the matter has been discussed with the Purchasing Agent who has informed me that the list price of this battery is $1295.00 and that if it had been purchased by the Department discounts would have been allowed which would have brought the cost down to $828.50, plus freight charges of $15.00 making a total of $843.50.

I am not prepared at the present time to submit this matter to the Minister for his approval until the need
for the purchase of the battery is fully gone into and you approve of the transfer of the amounts set aside for the other two schools.

If the Minister finally approves of the Department contributing towards the cost of the battery, I feel sure that he will limit the contribution to the amount that the battery would have cost if it had been purchased in the proper way.

The accounts attached to your memorandum are returned herewith.

Chief Executive Assistant.

Re: Joussard Indian Residential School.

Since September 1947 Reverend Father F. Sauve, who was formerly assistant principal at the Wabasca R.C. Residential School, has been assigned to the Joussard Indian Residential School for duty. This transfer of Father Sauve to Joussard has to a great extent improved the morale and the standard of the pupils of that school. This is especially noticeable with regards to the physical training program which Father Sauve has been able to direct to a high degree of efficiency. Father Sauve, as an instructor himself, has taken summer courses in physical training for several years and upon seeing the boys and girls perform one can readily notice that he is accomplishing a great step in Indian Education.

The number of boys and girls taking P.T. under Father Sauve is approximately 100. One great draw-back is the lack of space in the existing Residential School. While he is not asking for a gymnasium, Father Sauve informs me that he has been successful in obtaining some funds from private sources and that he is willing to undertake the building of the necessary room space outside of the Residential School. He is not asking for any assistance in so far as labour is concerned. The cost of material however, being so high, is estimated that he will need approximately $1,500.00 to purchase the required material to build this Physical Training Room.

Since this was unforeseen previously, it was not included in my 1948-49 estimates. If however there could be any possible
source where this money could be had from, I would recommend it to be a very valuable investment towards the health and education of the Indian Youth.

A. Landry,
Superintendent.

Ce matin je recevais un mot de M. Lapp, Notre Agent des Indiens, me disant qu'il deviendrait douteux que le Département nous accorderait le matériel demandé pour la construction de notre salle. Aussitôt je me suis embarqué et je suis allé le voir à son bureau à High-Prairie. Il me dit alors que nous avions manqué aux règlements d'achat auprès du Département et que, pour cette raison, il y avait grand doute qu'on nous accorde ce que nous avons demandé. Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Division,
Department of Mines and Resources
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

On reception of a letter from Mr. Lapp, our Indian Agent, of which I was really disappointed when I read the following: "There is some difficulty regarding the purchasing regulations so that it seems doubtful if the Department will supply the needed materials," I decided to write to you personally after having interviewed Mr. Lapp.

As this was my first occasion of asking a special grant from the Indian Department, I did not exactly know the purchasing regulations concerning such a grant, and therefore this explains why I went ahead as I did, purchasing lumber and nails at a real low price, expecting the Department to approve.

Being now aware that the Department claims that the Requisition For Supplies forms be filled and approved previous to any purchasing on our part, I therefore cancel all purchase orders already made, so as to be in order with all the Department regulations.

On suggestion of our Indian Agent, I inquired this morning in High-Prairie for local prices for needed materials of which a list is here enclosed on your requisition For Supplies forms.
I trust the utmost will be done to provide the needed materials for the building of a recreation hall that is so urgently needed here. Last Fall, we were forced, due to lack of space, to use the parochial church for that purpose which could not be available from year to year.

Trusting you are convinced as I am of the necessity of the physical fitness of our Indians... having gone so far as of having two of our staff members obtain certificates under the Health and Recreation Branch in Alberta... having been encouraged by Honourable Paul Martin and Doctor Plews to ask the help of the Indian Department... no local aid is altogether impossible... I ask you to please use your influence towards the Department to have our demand approved in the nearest future as I am presently ready to begin the building which should be completed for the next P.T. term beginning October the first.

Heartily thanking you,

I remain yours very truly,

[Ferdinand Sauvé's signature]

June 8th, 1949.

Mr Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

On reception of a letter from Mr. Lapp, our Indian Agent, of which I was really disappointed when I read the following: "There is some difficulty regarding the purchasing regulations so that it seems doubtful if the Department will supply the needed materials", I decided to write to you personally after having interviewed Mr. Lapp.

As this was my first occasion of asking a special grant from the Indian Department, I did not exactly know the purchasing regulations concerning such a grant, and therefore this explains why I went ahead as I did, purchasing lumber and nails at a real low price... expecting the Department to approve.

Being now aware that the Department claims that the Requisition For Supplies forms be filled and approved previous to any purchasing on our part, I therefore cancel all purchase orders already made, so as to be in order with all the Department regulations.

On suggestion of our Indian Agent I inquired this morning in High-Prairie for local prices for needed materials of which a list is here enclosed on your Requisition For Supplies form.
I trust the utmost will be done to provide the needed materials for the building of a recreation hall that is so urgently needed here. Last Fall, we were forced, due to lack of space, to use the parochial church for that purpose which could not be available from year to year.

Trusting you are convinced as I am of the necessity of the physical fitness of our Indians..., having gone so far as of having two of our staff members obtain certificates under the Health and Recreation Branch in Alberta..., having been encouraged by Honourable Paul Martin and Doctor Plews to ask the help of the Indian Department since local aid is altogether impossible..., I ask you to please use your influence towards the Department to have our demand approved in the nearest future as I am presently ready to begin the building which should be completed for the next P.T. term beginning October the first.

Heartily thanking you,

I remain yours very truly,

[Ferdinand Sauvionni]

Ottawa, January 23, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, enclosing applications and certificates of health for the admission of David Cardinal and Clara Ward to the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School, and, in reply, to inform you that the admission of these two pupils is approved. Please inform the Principal accordingly.

It is noted from the return of admission and discharges that pupil No. 0155, Agnes Sawan, died on October 21st, last. In this connection I would refer you to circular letter dated April 17th, 1935, in which it was stated that in future an enquiry be held immediately following the death of a pupil and that Form 414, containing the necessary information, should be completed and forwarded to the Department.

I would request that you forward this Form in connection with the death of pupil No. 0155, and you should see that, in future, in the case of the death of a pupil in any of the residential schools in your Agency, this Form is completed and forwarded promptly.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

N. P. L'Heureux, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Driftpile, Alta.

2. On receipt of the above mentioned wire, at 3:00 P.M., I left Kinuso via hired livery and patrolled to Jeusard
Mission on arrival I was met by Mr. L'Heureux, and he informed
me that a boy age 15 had set fire to the Mission School, and
that he wanted this matter investigated.

P.C.R.

3. I then interviewed Joe Morin and the following is a
statement given at his own free will:

"I came to the Catholic Mission at Jeusard in 1930,
and I have been attending school here ever since. On Sat-
urday morning January 23rd, about 10:00 o'clock, I was
talking to some boys, Germain Baudoin, Thomas Belrose, Son
L'Heureux; I told them that I didn't like to stay here any
more; I told them that I was going to burn the school. Then
I left the other boys and went playing outside. After
dinner I went again with Thomas Belrose to the entrance of
the school, and I lit a match and put it in a hole in the
wall of the school; then we went away. After about five
minutes Belrose and I came back to see if the fire had start-
ed. It hadn't, and the fire was cut; then both of us went
back to play. On Sunday at about 4:00 p.m. the four of us
went back to the entrance where I had previously started the
fire. I had some birch bark in my pocket, and I put it in
the same hole in the wall, and I lit it with a match, when
it started to burn. Then we all ran away. The other boys
went to the hall and I went to the barn to work. I intended
to burn the school, and on Saturday the Master gave me some
matches to burn some garbage, and I saved two to set fire
to the school, which I did on Sunday. My reason for burning
the school was that I didn't want to stay here any longer as
the boys were too rough. Son L'Heureux told me that we
should burn the school. I took my tool about out of the
school on Saturday before I set the fire as I wanted to save
it."

(Sgd. Joe Morin.)

Dear Sir,

Herewith the application of Mrs. Helen Jacknife Laboucan, No. 79 Driftpile Band, for the admission of her daughter, Elizabeth Cunningham, age 12, non-treaty, in Joussard Indian Residential School.

This child resides with her widowed mother who herself lives with her father near Sucker Creek Indian Reserve. They live the Indian mode of life; the mother earning sufficiently until two years ago for her living and that of her daughter. However for these two years, the scarcity of fur and game for hides from which she was deriving her revenue for living has caused destitution in her family and she is unable to provide for the education of her daughter.

Correcting the application, I must say that Elizabeth Cunningham has been in school one year already at the expense of St Bruno's Mission.

Re: Peter WILLIER, (Treaty) Jeansard, Alberta.

Juvenile Delinquent Act.

1. 8-12-37. I received a phone call from P.E. Gedye in the am that the Post Office had been entered during the night and several articles stolen, suspicion pointed to an Indian boy who had been in the Hamlet the previous night and who was then at the Emilda station. I had a mental patient in the cell at the time (Re: Vincent Groten - Panet, Alta., Mental Diseases Act.) who was to be handed over to Const. Gurril enroute to Edmonton via R.M.R. I decided to take patient with me to Emilda via P.C.R. 2350 I saw suspect in the station and called him on to the platform where he admitted the offence, then arrested the boy who said he was 16 years of age, after getting rid of my mental patient together with his effects by handing him over to Const. Gurril. I continued my investigation. I obtained a statement from this boy Peter Willier as follows:

"Emilda, Alberta, Dec. 8/37. Peter Willier (Treaty) states Dec. 8/37. I ran away from Catholic Mission at Jeansard and came to Driffield. No people were away. I slept there that night and left the next morning at 7:30 am and went to Pat Gampe's place. I stayed there till 11:30 am, Dec. 7th and left on the freight passed coal on the engine for my ride. I got off at Emilda about 2 pm and stayed in the Dufresne restaurant paid 15¢ for lunch & 10¢ for cigarettes. I got the latter from Waiters store.

I had been wandering around the Hamlet of Emilda all evening till about 10:30 pm. I was sitting in Gedye's store at Emilda and he told me that he was going to close up so I left and went to the station, there was a saboose here and I stayed in this place till about 11:30 pm. Then I broke the window in Gedye's store. I did not break into the store before because I have never been in Emilda before. I stole a ham, and ate part of this also some apples, bananas and sandwiches. I took $1.20 out of the till. I also stole a pair of leather cuffs, a leather belt, a pair of glasses, two watches, two brooches, two neckerchiefs, two rings, two knives, flashlight, hair overalls, shirt, sweater, pair of buckskin gloves, two boxes chocolates, neckerchief, five boxes cigarettes, five packets chewing gum, two pint lifesavers, two batteries and bulb, magnus lighter, one cigarette holder, matches, one flint, five bottles soft drinks.

(a) I have been staying at the Catholic Mission since September 8th, 1937. I found work, this is the first time I ever ran away. I did not leave the Mission during Nov., excepting to go to a dance at Jeansard about the 15th Nov. I have never been to Grouard or High Prairie.

(b) Once during Nov. 1937 I broke into the Mission warehouse at Jeansard and stole about 1 lb of brown sugar. I got in by the window, I unhooked the window, the glass of the window had been broken before. (F.T.O.)

Re: Peter Willier, (Treaty) Jossard, Alta.

Juvenile Delinquency Act

Statement of Peter Willier

1. Before, Henry George age 15 went with me when I got the sugar also George Ward age 14, the latter did not enter the warehouse we had a molasses bail that we carried the sugar in. I purchased a ticket from the money I stole from George's store, the ticket is from Enilda to Panet Number 20717. (Signed: Peter Willier.)

2. The above mentioned goods in this boy's statement were all found in his possession, entry: "Gedy's store was made by breaking the window in the Post Office which is about 2 ft square, as there is no one sleeping in this building which is also used as a general store and the living quarters being a good distance to the rear, I went forward and saw this boy committing the offense. The boy stated he ate part of the ham also drank several portions of pop and ate several biscuits apparently took his time. Having been informed from the Post Office, a search later revealed that a bunch of keys had been dropped by this boy whilst he was searching the till, one of the keys on this bunch is homemade there is also a brass tag with the following "$100.00 reward for return of keys if lost No.13060 will identify owner-on reverse side of tag - International Registry Co.,161 Broadway,N.Y., 17 Place D'Armes, Toronto, Dime Building, Toronto." When asked where he had got these keys Willier explained that when he went home he got them from the house also his Mother had found them but quite a long time ago.

3. The previous day Mr. Galibois clerk of the Indian Agency had phoned me (Dec.9/37) advising that Willier had run away from the Mission at Jossard and they suspected he had gone off in the bush to look for his Father who was out trapping about 25 miles away. Mr. Galibois had a party out then trying to get information on the boy and he was to give me more complete Information on the 8th Inst. When I arrested this boy I informed Mr. Galibois.

4. Upon phoning Sgt. Schulz of Rose River with a view to having Wm. Stewart J.J.O try this case, I was advised that Mr. Stewart suggested the boy be returned to the Catholic Mission at Jossard as Mr. Stewart was unable to be at High Prairie for some time being busy in other parts of the district; the boy however was kept at High Prairie till the 10th Inst. as I was unable to leave this district being kept busy with cases.

Re: Oscar Barry, High Prairie, Alta., Accidental death by shooting, Inquest in this case being held at High Prairie Dec.9/37 which lasted till late in the P.M.

5. Dec.10th, Accompanied by this juvenile I patrolled to Jossard via P.O.2350 and called on Rev. Fr. Serrano J.O. Mission, he advised me he was aware the boy had escaped the Mission, also that he had broken into the warehouse and stolen sugar, several other boys in the Mission were also interviewed and I ascertained that Peter Willier had been making brew in the bush near the Mission during the past summer with two other boys namely Eddy Calliou and George Anderson. Father Serrano stated that the Willier boy had caused considerable trouble in the Mission and he thought if an example was not made matters became worse.

6. With regard to the matter of bringing this case before the Juvenile court, this boy is already a ward of the Indian Department and attending the Mission under control of the Indian Agent, if he is allowed to return to the school after being before the Juvenile Judge it will have a bad moral effect on the other children, as it will appear that no punishment can be awarded other than returning them to the Mission School for discipline, the boy does not seem to realise the seriousness of his offence and rather boastful character leaves the impression that the other pupils that he has distinguished himself by his acts and is looked upon as a hero.

7. I questioned this boy for quite a time as this is the second time Gedy's store has been entered within a month, also the Post Office at Gedy's and it was rather strange that this boy who states he has never been to Enilda or Grouard before should E.A. Steal the first occasion especially a store such as Gedy's where it is not occupied during the night, but continued questioning failed to reveal any further evidence. The parents of this boy are absent at present I intend to question them when they return also Pat Gamble where this boy stayed just before he caught the stage to travel for Enilda.

8. The goods stolen in this instance were left at the store of F.W.Gedy's where they are set aside to be used as exhibits where this boy is brought before the Juvenile Court, the boy himself handed these articles back to Mr. Gedy when he was being questioned. (F.R.)
Could I be advised if the Indian Department have any suggestion before this case is brought to court.

Dear Sir:

I have just been thinking about your telephone message last night asking me to try a case at Driftpile against a treaty Indian woman for refusing to send her children to the R.C.Mission School at Jussard. As Driftpile is just outside my regular district I must get the permission of the Deputy Attorney General to go there.

If I remember correctly this is the same woman, who with her father, had an argument some months ago with the Indian Agent in your office about this same trouble. I gathered from the argument that the seat of the trouble is religious differences and the woman had decided opinions on the matter, and for that reason the trouble will have to be approached with care and fairness.

I am not sure that a case of this kind should be brought into the police court.

Under Section 10 of the Indian Act the Superintendent General designates the school to which the children must attend and I would suggest that the matter be laid before him as he might fix some other school, because I understand there is another school to which this woman is perfectly willing to send her children. It might be a little difficult to get the matter before the Superintendent through the Indian Agent, as you told me and I gathered the same from the argument that he is determined that these children shall go to the Jussard Mission School.

I do not relish the idea of getting mixed up in this religious quarrel as that is just what it appears to me at present.

As soon as I hear from the Deputy Attorney General I will get in touch with you but in any case I will not be able to get down your way before the second week of January as I have a trip west and besides I have the Debt Adjustment work to look after and that keeps me glued to my desk a large part of the time.

Yours truly,

Re: Peter Willier, (Treaty) Jossard, Alta.

Juvenile Delinquency Act

Statement of Peter Willier

On December 15th, Henry George age 16 went with me when I got the sugar. Also George Ward age 14, the latter did not enter the warehouse. We had a policeman with us who carried the sugar in. I purchased a ticket from the man who stole from Gaddy's store. The ticket is from Edmonton to Fort Macleod. (Signed: Peter Willier)

2. The above mentioned goods in this boy's statement were all found in his possession, except a bottle of pop which was broken by breaking the window in the Fort Office. It is said that Mr. Willier was seen in some shopping in this building which is also used as a general store, and the living quarters being a good distance to the rear no one heard or saw this boy committing the offense. The boy stated he ate part of the ham and drank several bottles of pop and ate several biscuits apparently took his time, nothing was missed from the Post Office. A search later revealed that a bunch of keys had been dropped by this boy whilst he was searching the till. One of the keys on this bunch is house key there is also a brass key with the following: "$100.00 reward for return of missing keys." This key was given to Mr. Willier by Mr. International Telegraph Co., 101 Broadway, N.Y., M. Anne D'Amour, Montreal, Quebec Building, Toronto. When asked where he had got these keys Willier explained that when he went home he got them from the house also his Mother had found these keys quite a long time ago.

3. The previous day Mr. Galibois clerk of the Indian Agency had phoned me (Dec.7/37) advising that Willier had run away from the Mission at Jossard and they suspected he had gone off in the bush to look for his Father who was out trapping about 35 miles away. Mr. Galibois had a copy of the warrant and got information on the boy but he was unable to give me more complete information on the 8th Inst., when I arrested this boy. I informed Mr. Galibois.

4. Upon phoning Sgt. Schulz of Peace River with a view to having him Stewart try this case, I was advised that Mr. Stewart suggested the boy be returned to the Ochota Mission at Jossard as Mr. Stewart was unable to be at High Prairie for some time being busy in other parts of the district. The boy however was held at High Prairie until the 10th Inst. as I am unable to leave this district being kept busy with cases. Mr. Stewart, High Prairie, has promised additional details of proceedings in this case being held at High Prairie Dec.9/37 which lasted till late in the P.M.

5. Dec.10th. Accompanied by this juvenile I patrolled to Jossard via Ft. Macleod and called on Rev. Mr. Barrand 1/2 Mile, Mission, he advised me he was aware the boy had escaped the Mission, also that he had broken into the warehouse and stolen sugar. Several other boys in the Mission were also interviewed and I ascertained that Peter Willier had been making brew in the bush near the Mission during the past summer with two other boys named Smith and Wilson. Mr. Barrand stated that he had heard of the Willier boy and caused considerable trouble in the Mission and he thought if an example was not made matters become serious.

6. With regard to the matter of bringing this case before the Juvenile court, this boy is already a ward of the Indian Department and attending the Mission under control of the Indian Agent. If he is allowed to return to this school after being before the Juvenile Judge it will have a bad moral effect on the other children, as it will appear that no punishment can be awarded other than returning them to the Mission School for discipline, thus setting a very bad example to others. I believe the other pupils that he has distinguished himself by his acts and is looked upon as a hero.

7a. I questioned this boy for quite a time as this is the second time Gaddy's store has been entered within a month, also the Post Office at Jossard and it was rather strange that this boy who states he has never been to Edmonton or Grouard before should have stolen the first occasion especially a store such as Gaddy's where it is not occupied during the night, but during the daytime. Furthermore there was another witness. The witnesses of this case are absent at present. I intend to question them when they return, also Mr. Gaddy where this boy stayed just before he caught the freight train for Edmonton.

8. The goods stolen in this instance were left at the store of Mr. Gaddy where they are set aside to be used as exhibits when this boy is brought before the Juvenile Court, the boy himself handed these articles back to Mr. Gaddy when he was being questioned. (220)

Dear Sir,

With reference to the application herewith for the admission of Floris Laboucan at Joussard Indian Residential School.

On Christmas eve while the pupils were going to attend church service, the father of the child came along, pulled his daughter from the rank without the guardian noticing it, carried her to his vehicle and hastened home. This was done without the permission of the Principal nor mine. St Germain Laboucan was requested to take the child back to the mission school but he was adamant in his determination to keep her. On January 3rd, the matter was reported to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police at High Prairie. This officer came immediately to this office with the School Principal who had joined him at Joussard. If prosecution had become necessary to enforce the return of the child to school, it was found that a case of this nature is not specifically covered by any section of the Indian Act; the nearest but not quite meeting the requirements of the case being Sec. 10, s-s 4. The suggestion was made that Sec. 316, (a) and (b) of the Criminal Code, respecting abduction, might apply, the proviso being added that the priority of rights to the child as between the Director of Indian Affairs under the Indian Act and the father of the child should have to be established.

Prosecution was not necessary as the father obeyed the warning of the R.C.M.P. to take his child to school which he did the next day. However as a similar case may recur which may require Court action I would like to be advised of the procedure to follow and the Acts and section under which to prosecute to secure indictment.

Yours faithfully,

N. P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of the 14th instant, your file No. 131-4-10, stating your decision in the case of Peter Willier and requesting a report in the case of an Indian woman refusing to send her child to Joussard Residential School.

I beg to advise that this woman is Mrs. Frank Kissay-nees-Cardinal, No. 44 Sucker Creek Band. She has a child, Florence who has now reached statutory school age. Since the beginning of the September school term, this family has been visited several times by the principal of the Residential School to induce her to send her child to school, the father of the child was quite willing but the mother refused. Upon the matter being referred to me I interviewed Cardinal and his wife, first on October 2nd and later on the 15th. On the last interview she refused in no uncertain terms, the husband taking no part in the discussion. Besides the near abusive language she used, she stated that the reason why she would not send her child to school was because "they learned nothing in those schools". In view of the grossly unfair language used by her and poor value of the reason given I called in the R.C.M.P. Constable from High Prairie who served the statutory three-days notice as required by Section 10, sub-section 4, to have her bring her child to school. This notice was not heeded to and on December 27th a second notice was served by the R.C.M.P. Police. To date it has had no effect; the child is not in the Residential School nor in the District Public School where the woman stated to the R.C.M.P. that she wanted to send her child to.

I recommend that this case be brought to Court in order that I may obtain authority to take the child Florence into the Joussard Residential School.

There is also a similar case on Driftpile Reserve which I want to be dealt with through the Court. John Felix Beaver, No. 78 Driftpile Band, who has a child of school age whom he steadfastly refuses to send to school. On the 7th or 8th of December he called

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,

at the office in an angry mood because I had asked his father to urge him to send his child to school and he threw his treaty ticket at me saying that he was not treaty any longer and he departed.

I would say that at the beginning of the school term I have had eleven cases of families refusing to send or return their children to school; it has taken much cajoleries and an insistence of every moment to bring nine of these cases to reason; and I say that if those two cases are let off without the Indian Act being enforced or other means taken to insure that those two children are placed in a school to receive an education, I am afraid that we will have many vacancies in our Residential Schools next term.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 21st instant with reference to the difficulty you have experienced in having the children of Mrs. Frank Kissaynees-Cardinal and John Felix Beaver attend school.

In view of the information contained in your letter the Department approves the necessary action being taken under Section 10 of the Indian Act.

You should, of course, arrange with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police to serve the notice required under Subsections 3 and 4 of Section 10. If the children are not placed in the school designated by you within 3 days of the date of notice action may be taken under Subsection 4.

May I direct your attention to the following amendment to the Indian Act which was assented to 23rd May, 1933:

"Section ten of the Indian Act, chapter ninety-eight of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1927, is amended by adding thereto the following subsection:

"(6) For the purposes of this section, every member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Force and any special constable appointed for police duty on an Indian reserve, shall be a truant officer."
