January 27, 1935.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant and my reply of the 10th instant a report has recently been received from Indian Agent L'Heureux with reference to the difficulty he has experienced in arranging for the education of the children of Mrs. Frank Kissaynees-Cardinal, No. 44 Sucker Creek Band, and John Felix Beaver, No. 78 Driftpile Band.

These parents have persistently refused to educate their children and unless the necessary action is taken under Section 10 of the Indian Act it is quite likely that other Indian parents will follow their example.

Under the above circumstances the Department is instructing Indian Agent L'Heureux to proceed against these parents under the Act and I would appreciate if you would notify Police Magistrate Stewart that Mr. L'Heureux's action against these parents is being taken with our approval.

Subsection 4 of Section 10 of the Act provides that on summary conviction before a Justice of the Peace the Indian parent refusing to send his children to school renders himself liable to either fine or imprisonment and that his children of school age may be arrested without a warrant and conveyed to school by the

J. W. McClung, Esq.,
Attorney General's Dept.,
Edmonton, Alta.
truant officer. The Department is not anxious to register either fines or jail sentences on parents but our primary desire is to have the children given an opportunity of obtaining an education.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

R. A. Hoey
Chief Training Division
Ottawa.

Sir:

Being in possession of a copy of your letter sent to Mr. L'Heureux, (File 131 - 4 - 10, Jan. 14th, 1938) I would like to let you know how matters stand here concerning some children seven years old and in good health not being in school, so you may understand well the situation and understand why I am asking the Department to enforce the Indian Act as far as the attendance at school is concerned.

Several children of school age were kept home since September, for no reason whatever only through ill will and caprice of their parents. No complaint of any kind having been made against the school. They were kept home also against the will of the children, who if they were free would come to school to be well dressed and well fed, (that's their own words). I warned those people that according to the Indian Act they were compelled to send their children to school and if they failed to do so, a complaint would be laid against them: they would be judged and punished and children would be taken to school.

This I did because I knew that the Indians who had sent their children to school wanted the others to do the same, and also because it was the wish (expressed many times) of the chiefs and councillors. Consequently those parents were served summons.

At first they did not pay much attention to the summons being under the impression we were running a mere bluff; later on having found we meant business, they changed their mind and sent their children to school with the exception of two. Now according to me those people should be prosecuted with the results that chiefs and councillors and other Indians will be very glad to see that not only some but all Indians must comply with the Indian Act. While if they were not obliged to follow the Indian Act, all the others would be dissatisfied and jealous; so the agent, the constable and the principal would be looked at as bluffers and would be the laughing stock of the reserve. So those children sent to school through fear of prosecution would be taken away for one reason or another. And next year other children would not come. So we would never see the end of our trouble, and finally the Indian Act would be dead letter for our Indians.

So my conclusion is and I hope it is yours: let us enforce
enforce the law and see the end of our troubles.

Yours respectfully

Rev. Paul Serrand
Principal

Re: Peter Willier:

If you are kind enough to allow me to tell you why I cannot reconcile with the Department's decision, I would do so. To the child having committed a serious offense should be punished according to the natural law - The child himself was sure to be punished and so were the parents and the people of the reserve. So I am afraid this decision is liable to induce other children to do the same as did Peter Willier. This child told his parents I stole because I wanted to be put out of school; (I do not think it is the truth); yet he tries to make that impression around him.

Will not children lonesome at school be induced to do the same? I am afraid they will.

Those are the reasons why I cannot reconcile myself with the Department's decision.

Is it too late to have this decision altered? May be not, the chief's father is in the bush and will not be back for another month.

P.S.
Ottawa,
January 31, 1938.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 24th instant the Department has written Indian Agent L'Heureux authorizing him to proceed under the compulsory clause of the Indian Act against Mrs. Frank Kissaynees-Cardinal, No. 44 Sucker Creek Band, and John Felix Beaver, No. 75 Driftville Band, who have refused to place their children in school.

I regret that you do not agree with the decision that has been made regarding Peter Willier. Might I point out that after making very extensive inquiries it was not found possible to locate any institution in the Province of Alberta to which this boy could be sent. I feel you will agree that it is not likely that he would profit by being sent to any of the regular penal institutions. His case received very careful consideration but after considering all the circumstances in the case we felt that there was no other action could be taken than to return him to his father.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

On the 17th of March in A.M., Rev. Father Serrand phoned me up and stated that Felix Beaver had just taken his son, Victor, away from school and was on his way to Driftpile. I immediately wired Const. Duff to come out, stop Beaver and take the child back to the Mission. When the police arrived the Indian had already reached home and both Beaver and his wife opposed themselves strongly, when the R.C.M.P. tried to take the boy away, saying that the latter was sick. Nurse Fisk was then called to the scene, and upon examination she said that the child, who had just recovered from a slight grippe and who had been exposed to the cold during his long trip home with practically no clothes on, was probably developing a bad cold or a pneumonia, so she advised that he be sent to hospital. To that, again, the parents strongly opposed themselves, and it was decided to allow the boy to remain at home until he would be fit to return to school. Miss Fisk then came back to the agency to get the medicine she needed to treat the child, but when she returned to Beaver's house, the mother dared her to touch her son, so the nurse could not do anything and had to come back. The following morning, when Miss Fisk went to visit them, Beaver had closed the gate with barbed wire. The nurse, however, returned a few days later and found the boy, Victor, fit to go back to school. Beaver was notified to take his son to the Mission not later than Saturday the 26th, but he did not do so arguing that Victor was still sick, so on Monday the 27th, I called out Const. Duff, and he with Nurse Fisk took the boy to St. Bruno's school.

N.F.L. Heureux,
Indian Agent.

It is not possible to consider payment of per capita grant for Clara Giroux who is stated to have been omitted from the return during the past four years.

Headquarters
1. With reference to the above, I beg to report that in
the PM of August 30th, the writer was informed that
the above party has informed Mr. N.P.L'Heureux - Indian
Agent at Driftpile to the effect that she would not send
her two sons - Vincent GROUX - age 10 years; & Leo GROUX
- age 7 years to school at the residential Indian School
at Jousnard, Alta.

Sub-Division
2. Mr. L'Heureux requested assistance in this matter. In
the PM of same date I sent word over to the above party
that I wished to see her about her two boys; at about 7.00
PM of same date this woman called at this Detachment with
her father Benjamin GROUX, and her two boys - Vincent &
Leo, and stated that the boys were ready to go to school,
and requested that I arrange for their transportation.

Detachment
3. In PM of same date the two boys were placed in my
private car, and conveyed to the Indian Agency at Driftpile,
where the matter was reported to Mr. L'Heureux, and he
requested that I convey the boys to the Jousnard Indian
Residential School that same night, and that he would
notify the Father in charge of the arrival of the boys.
The boys were conveyed, and handed over to the Father in
charge of the School, and the writer returned to Detachment
at 11.00 PM of same date. File closed at this Detachment.

1. With reference to the above, I beg to report that in the PM of 1st. inst. Father Kindervater R.S. Priest called at this detachment and reported that the above child Jerome CHALIFOUX - age 14 yrs. had refused to attend school, and requested that Police attend to this case.

2. In the PM of 2nd. inst. patrol was made via pte. car east to the Assiniboia Det., where I located August CHALIFOUX, father of the above named, and he stated that his boy was not going to school at the present time, as he was working. I informed this man as to the penalty which would follow if a charge was laid against him under the Indian Act (Sec. 19), but he stated that he did not know that he was doing wrong. The Father immediately brought the boy back to camp from the bush where he was working, and prepared him for school. Patrol continued on other Trusney children investigations, and delivered the boy - Jerome CHALIFOUX - to the Indian Mission in Jonssard, Alta. in PM of same date and returned to Det. 6:45 PM of same date. Ottawa,
October 28, 1941.

AIR MAIL

Reverend Sir:

I am returning the September quarter return of the Joussard Residential School as I feel that you have not requested the amount of grant which we are prepared to allow.

The Department is aware of the fact that the schools in Alberta were closed for a considerable period during September for medical reasons.

It has been decided to pay per capita allowance for the period the schools were under quarantine.

Consequently, for any pupils in residence in the Joussard School on July 1, who were allowed home on holidays and who returned promptly upon the expiration of the quarantine period, grant will be allowed for the full 92 days. In the case of pupils in residence on June 30 and discharged at that date grant will be allowed for 62 days. This is the holiday period and it has been our custom to allow holiday leave.

For pupils admitted to the school for the first time during the September quarter grant will be allowed from the date of admission to the end of the quarter.

Yours truly,

Rev. P. Serrand,
Principal,
Joussard Indian Residential School,
Joussard, Alta.

Re: Indian Children Attending Public Schools

On the 10th Inst. I received from the Principal of the Jeussard (St.Emilien's) R.C. Indian Residential School a list of Treaty Indian Children who had not been taken to that school since the opening date and who were still absent. I made an inquiry into this matter and when I questioned Tr. No. 27, Alfred Giroux of the Kinnaayo Band at Driftpile he stated that he did not intend to place his child in the Mission but was intending to enroll the child in the local Public school. He gave as his reason that the children do not learn anything at the Missions; that he attended for 9 years and learned nothing and that the children at the Missions were not properly clothed or fed.

Giroux mentioned other Indians who intended following his plan with regard to their children who had reached school age. I am mentioning the Giroux case as he is inclined to be an agitator and has been moving among the Indians and persuading them to follow his example. At the time of the payment of the annual annuity this year several Bands requested the setting up of day schools on the reserves to replace the Missions. This feeling is becoming more marked each year I believe.

On the receipt of the letter from the Principal and having enquired into the facts of this case I perused the pertinent sections of the Indian Act and I believe that the Indians are acting unlawfully in this matter. I have not taken action to have these children removed from the Mission pending receipt of a definite ruling as Giroux stated that he had been advised by the Inspector that he could put his children into any school if he was willing to meet the cost. There is the possibility that Giroux is mistaken, or not telling the truth, which fact I can ascertain when Mr. Schmidt visits this Agency which he intends to do this month. Before I take any further action I would very much appreciate instructions for my future guidance as it would seem that some fixed policy with regard to this should be followed through out the agency.

W.B. Skead
for
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
September 27, 1943.

AIR MAIL

Mr. C.F. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alta.

I am in receipt of a letter from W.B. Skead, Driftpile, Alberta, in which he states that you expect to visit that agency in the near future. Consequently I thought it advisable to communicate with you at once.

Mr. Skead's letter refers to the fact that a number of the children enrolled at the Joussard Indian Residential School did not return to the school upon the expiry of the summer holidays and, when Mr. Skead endeavoured to return them, several of the Indians, particularly Alfred Giroux, No. 87 of the Kinnosayo Band, stated that they did not want their children to return to Joussard, but that they intended to place them in white schools at their own expense.

If Giroux or any other Indian wishes to place his children in a white school at his own expense the Department has no objection, but too often this is only an excuse for keeping them home because it would probably be some time before our officials would know if the children were actually attending the white school regularly. With this in mind we favour the return of the children to the Joussard Residential School, or to whatever residential school in which they should be placed.
The Department would appreciate it if you would investigate the matter thoroughly when you are in the Lesser Slave Lake Agency and let us have a report.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Calgary, October 13th, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I have for acknowledgment your letter No. 151-4-10 of the 27th ultimo, re Indians of the Lesser Slave Lake Agency — particularly Alfred Giroux, No. 87, Kinsessay Band, Driftpile, not wanting to return their children to the Joussard Residential School; but that they wanted to place them in White schools at their own expense.

I beg to report that while at the Lesser Slave Lake Agency on the 6th instant, I interviewed Alfred Giroux, aged 34 years, himself an ex-pupil, he having attended the Joussard School for nine years. He has two boys: one, his son Guy, aged 7 years; the other, his nephew Leonard, aged 7 years, adopted, an orphan, son of Emil Giroux, deceased.

The reasons advanced by Giroux for not wanting to send the boys to the Joussard Residential School, were:

"The children do not learn much in the residential school; some of them become bad boys and use swear words; some of them steal; some of the older boys are rough on small boys (new ones -- beginners). My boy sometimes walks in his sleep so I want his mother to take care of him. I live not two miles from the Driftpile Rural Public School; I want my boys to go there; I can pay what it will cost."

In reply to my questions, Giroux said:

"Yes, I had some unpleasantness with the Principal; he refused to help me to build a frame granary; he helped others, but would not help me (on credit); I was sorry and said: 'Alright, the time will come when I will have my children of age to go to school, and they will not go to the residential school!' Yes, on the information of the Principal, I was prosecuted and fined for being intoxicated at the school one time at Christmas; No, I do not hate the Principal now; I forget that. There were some lies told at that time. I got so I won't do what the Agent asks me to do; I do not like him. Yes, the Principal sold me some lumber on time since then -- $9.00 worth; I paid it."

It was obvious when I first talked to Giroux, that he had a "chip on his shoulder" and was sore at the Principal and the Agent. I brought it out of him, and he admitted that he was very negligent, not to say that he refused to pay his debts, due through the Agency books, even though he could do so; as he admits that he has had considerable sums of cash pass through his hands. I told him that I believed he was wrong in surmising that both the Agent and the Principal were against him, and would not help him, and told him, "Play the game fairly; if you get credit, pay your debts; you were fined for drunkenness at the school on Christmas: Accept the rap and don't do it again." I then pointed out to him that we had a very good school at Joussard, which he finally admitted.

I told him that we preferred having the Indian children attend our own residential schools, where we give them everything they need: lodging, food, clothing, medical attention and care, education and good training.

(Over)
I told him, that if for valid or serious reasons an Indian wishes to place his children in an outside school, the Department would agree to this, on the recommendation of the Indian Agent or the Inspector of Indian Agencies; but only on the clear and distinct understanding that the children would be punctual and attend very regularly at all seasons, and that the parents pay all tuition fees to the School Board.

I then informed him that the reasons he had advanced were not sufficient for me to recommend the sending of the two young boys (beginners) to an outside school, and I would recommend to the Department that they be placed in the Joussard Residential School, the nearest to his home, some ten (10) miles away, telling him that if he did not like this school there was plenty of room for the boys at the Grouard Residential School, some thirty (30) miles further away. He appeared to have changed his attitude before leaving me; I think he will send both boys to the Joussard School.

Later that day the Provincial School Inspector, Mr. Stehlin, spoke to Acting Indian Agent Skead on the telephone, to tell him that they did not want Indian children in their school at Kinuso; that they did not have any room for them. I later made enquiries, of Mr. Pickford, the local merchant at Driftpile, re the standing of the Driftpile School mentioned by Giroux; we were told that this school would not reopen this autumn as there were not sufficient pupils to warrant engaging a teacher. I did not meet Giroux again before leaving, but asked Acting Indian Agent Skead to inform him of this, and advise him to send his children to Joussard School at once.

In conversation with the Reverend Principal of the Joussard School, he stated that there was no difficulty encountered as regards pupils returning to school, but that it was the admission of new pupils that Alfred Giroux appeared to be opposing, and that he understood that he (Giroux) had spoken to one, Ambroise Giroux, re his daughter Edna, aged 7 years, also to Harry No Hat, re his son Adolphus, aged 7 years, re sending their children to Driftpile School, but that the latter two were not in favour of this. The Principal stated that a few had been late in coming back; that in one case he had permitted a girl (laboucan) to remain home for a couple of weeks because of her mother's illness (maternity). Two others, Angelique, aged 8 years, daughter of Ed Willier, and the step-son of Harry No Hat, mentioned above, had not yet returned, but were expected to return in a few days' time. He added, that apart from Alfred Giroux, who is somewhat of an agitator, he had no trouble with the other Indians, and found the children happy in school.

Re that part of the third paragraph of Const. Skead's letter, wherein he says that Giroux states that .. "he had been advised by the Inspector that he could put his children into any school if he was willing to meet the cost"; I asked Giroux, in the presence of Mr. Skead, who this inspector was; he appeared somewhat embarrassed; then said: "The one before you came." I did not check him closely on this, but remarked to him that I have been in Alberta since 1937 and had made my first visit to that Agency in May of that year.

C. Pant. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Chief, Training Division.
Driftpile Alberta
Dec. 20th. 1943.

Dept. of Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Canada.

I have had an interview with Mr. Paul Sowan of Swan River Band No. 17, who called at the Agency this morning, regarding his children. Mr. Sowan resides on the reserve, but tells me that he owns some property in the Hamlet of Kinuso, and pays taxes there to the Kinuso School District. He wants to have his children attend the school there instead of sending them to the Indian Residential School at Joussard. I was in Kinuso last week on some other business, and while I was there, I was interviewed by Mr. Boisvert, Chairman of the local school Board, and one of the other Trustee's, whom I do not recall the name, and they expressed the desire that these Indian children should not be allowed to attend their School. The first reason given by them, was that they were very short of room, and that if the children of both Paul and August Sowan were permitted to attend their school, it would eventually lead to more Indians wanting to do likewise. They did not seem to want these children at their School.

On this same day when I was in Kinuso, Mr. August Sowan spoke to me about his children, and his desire was to send them to Kinuso also. His reasons for doing so were in my estimation very poor. His first reason was that the children at the Mission Schools learned to steal, and that there was too much time spent at praying. Those were the only two reasons given by him.

I would appreciate it very much to have your decision on this question by return Air-Mail, as they want to have their children start school right after New Years. My recommendation is that they should return to the Mission School at Joussard.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
December 23, 1943.

Mr. P.J. Demers, Indian Agent, Driftpile, Alta.

I have your letter of the 20th instant, with reference to the children of Paul and August Sowan. After carefully considering the contents of your letter the Department feels that these children should return to the Joussard Residential School. It is hoped that you will be able to arrange to have them sent back at an early date.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. P. J. Demers, Indian Agent, Driftpile,
via Kinuso, Alberta.

With reference to the December quarter return of the Joussard Residential School, pupil No. 180 Thomas Bellrose was shown on the September quarter return as 16 years of age. This agreed with our records as shown on the original application form. On the December quarter return this boy is stated to be 14 years of age. Please discuss this matter with the Principal and let me have an explanation.

Pupil No. Q250 Elsie Ward was evidently absent from the school for the December quarter 1943, and also the March and June quarters of 1944, as no request was made for any grant for her during those three quarters. On the September quarter return grant was requested and allowed for this girl for 92 days. Her name is shown on the December quarter return but no grant is requested and it therefore appears that she is again absent from the school. I would appreciate some explanation regarding her.

Pupils 243 and 244 are shown on the return and grant requested for the full quarter. In this regard I would refer you to my letter of November 13, 1943, and letter of April 14, 1944, also your reply of April 21, 1944. The admission of these children was originally refused, due to the fact that they were not considered Treaty Indians. Has their status been changed in the meantime?

We have not yet received the eight
application forms requested in my letter of October 24, 1944. These covered the new pupils who had entered the Joussard School for the first time during the September quarter.

Paul Chalifoux No. 206 was transferred to the Grouard Residential School in March, 1944. On the December quarter return of the Joussard School grant was requested for him for 92 days. Has he been transferred back to Joussard from Grouard?

Feb. 9th. 1945.

Dept. of Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Canada.

I wish to bring to your attention the following, and would appreciate your advice;

On January 25th, 1945, Paul Chalifoux, No.345 Grouard School, Jack Willier No.215, Archie NoHat, No.219 and Dan G. Theodore No.214 of Joussard School, ran away from the Joussard School. I wish to state that Paul Chalifoux was also attending the Joussard School since the opening term in September. Jack, Archie and Dan were returned to school on the 26th, the next day, and Paul is still at home. Paul Chalifoux was a source of trouble at Joussard last year, and it was on account of this that he was transferred to Grouard, and while he was there to finish the term last year, he was a very good boy and caused no further trouble. On Sept. last when the time came for Paul to return to school, Francis Chalifoux, the guardian of this boy did not want him to go back to Grouard, but consented on having him attend the Joussard School. This I agreed to on the understanding that if Paul did not cause any trouble there, he would be allowed to remain there, but if he ran away from school, as he had done last winter, he would again be transferred to Grouard. This the guardian (Francis Chalifoux) agreed to.

The point now raised, is that Francis Chalifoux does not want Paul to back to any school, as he says that he is needed at home to help his wife Mary Chalifoux, the mother of this boy. I might say that Mary Chalifoux is the lawful wife of Jimmie Walker, #53, Sucker Creek, but they have been separated for quite a number of years, and she has been living with her father and mother, Mr. & Mrs. Francis Chalifoux. She also claims that this boy Paul is needed at home to help her, as she is alone with her mother and three children, one who is a sick baby since he was born, and requires special attention, and another boy of 5 years of age, who
is medically unfit to be at school. This family is not in good financial circumstances, as they are getting monthly rations from the Agency, and their only means of existence, is for Francis to work out for a living, and provide for the rest of the family. Francis is now 62 years of age, and is hardly able to be at hard work continually. I quite agree that this boy can assist his mother at home, but on the other hand, if this boy had not run away from school, there would have been nothing said about it.

I also told the parents of this boy that if they would let him go back to school; I would assist them with firewood, clothing and perhaps some extra food, but they refused. They also have as an excuse that there are four boys of 14 years of age, who are not attending school, and they feel that if their boy is compelled to return to school, these other boys should also go. I explained to them that of these four boys, one was medically unfit, having a Doctor's certificate, and the other three are needed at home, but they do not seem to want to understand this.

My honest opinion is that, I am satisfied that this boy can be of help at home, as he is healthy and strong, and not lazy by any means, but on the other hand, if this boy is allowed to stay at home, I am afraid that there will be other boys from the Jeunebard School, who will try and do the same thing. Therefore I would appreciate very much getting your advice in this particular case.

Please reply by Air Mail.

P.J. Demers
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 15, 1945.

Mr. P. J. Demers, Indian Agent, Driftpile, Alberta.

I have your letter of the 9th instant, with reference to Paul Chalifoux, pupil No. 206 of the Joussard Residential School. The quarterly return states that this boy is only 13 years of age, and if this information is correct it would appear doubtful if he would be of any great value at home. If he is discharged now, it simply means that he does not receive any more education, as it is extremely unlikely that he would ever return to school. There is the further fact, as stated in your letter, that if we discharge him it would probably encourage others to make similar application.

I think you should again discuss the matter with the Principal and probably the latter and yourself could have another interview with the guardian, and at that time you might point out to him the desirability of his taking more interest in the boy by allowing him to continue his education at least until the close of the current academic year.

Re: Capot-Blanc Children.
Treaty Indians - Keg River, Alta.

1. On the P.M. of the 24-2-45, Dr. G. Jackson of Keg River, Alta., contacted this detachment and requested assistance in the transportation of the above children from Peace River to Joussard. Dr. Jackson was in Peace River with 18 Indian Children who were being checked at the T.B. Clinic at this point. The three Capot-Blanc children, Agnes age 10 yrs., Evelyn age 7 and Madalain age 4 had been left homeless at Keg River when their mother died in January of this year. The father of the children is Napoleon Capot-Blanc, is at the present time on his trap-line at Ft. Nelson, B.C. and apparently cannot be contacted.

2. Dr. Jackson stated that she had endeavoured to reach Peace River in time to catch the N.A.Rly train on the 24-2-45 but they had arrived after the train had departed. She had also attempted to get in touch with the Indian Agent at Briftnile to make arrangements for the care of the children but with negative results. The children had been in the Joussard Indian Mission School up until a short time prior to the mother's death.

3. Phone call was made to the High Prairie Detachment and arrangements were made to meet the High Prairie Det. P.C. at McLennan in the P.M. of the 25-2-45. Accordingly, patrol was made by the writer as arranged via P.C. 5223 with the three Capot-Blanc children and Cst. McCullough of the High Prairie Det. was met near McLennan and the three children were handed over to him for further transportation.

ATTENTION MR. PHELAN

I wish to draw to your attention the fact that about 14 Indian children of the Driftpile Reserve, have not yet reported for school attendance at the Joussard Indian Residential School, and would respectfully request that you tell me just what to do with these children.

On Sept. 14th, the parents and guardians of these children were all notified in writing that if their children did not report for school by Sept. 20th, legal proceedings would be taken against them as under Sec. 10 of the Indian Act. Since these notices were sent, quite a few of the children reported for school, but there are still about 14 who have not. I wish to state that there is no school at Driftpile, and they cannot attend school at Faust, as they cannot get admission there for lack of room, and therefore are not going to school anywhere. If I lay a charge against them, they are going to have a lawyer to defend their case, and I would necessarily have to get one also, as there will be strong opposition to meet. This would also have to appear before the Magistrate, as the local J.P. does not want to have anything to do with it, and the Magistrate's fees would have to be paid. I would certainly appreciate receiving your instructions as to what to do, so as to settle this matter once and for all.

P.J. Demers
Indian Agent.

Dept. of Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

ATTENTION MR. PHELAN,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 9th inst. File 131-4-10, re Indian Residential School at Joussard, and wish to give you the information asked for.

The number of children whose parents have refused to send them to school, are as follows:

| Location       | Number |
|----------------|--------|
| Driftpile      | 19     |
| Sucker Creek   | 3      |
| Total          | 22     |

I might add that the parents of some of these children had made up their minds to send their children to Public schools at Faust and Kinuso, but all the public schools within a radius of 50 miles from here, definitely refuse to admit Indian children to their schools. The reasons are, lack of accommodation, cost of operation and not very anxious to have them mix with white children. This has been agreed upon between Inspector's, Sthein of McLennan and Inspector Hodgson of Athabasca. Therefore these children are not attending any school, and they still refuse to send them to the Joussard Indian Residential School. I have done all I could to have them return, but have not succeeded for the above mentioned children.

(over)
It is not a question of Family Allowances which prevents them from going to school, but mainly obstinacy, for various reasons, such as not sufficient food, do not learn enough English etc., which is all false, as I have carefully gone through this matter with the Principal, Rev. P. Serrand, and have found out that these children are adequately fed, with good food, and also kept very clean. This school is known to be the best in our Agency.

I might also add that all our Indian Residential Schools in this Agency, are not experiencing very much difficulty in having the children return to school, and generally speaking, the attendance is very good.

Since every means of having these children return to school has failed, I would respectfully request that get your permission to enforce Sec. 10 of the Indian Act, and that authority be given for paying the Magistrate's Fees in connection therewith.

Please Air Mail your reply.

P.J. Demers
Indian Agent.

The following is a brief report on the attendance
of children from Driftpile and Sucker Creek Reserves to
the Joussard Residential School as at this date.

On February 22nd, Mr. J.E. Morris held a meeting
of the Driftpile Band, and at this meeting Mr. Morris
emphasized to the parents of all school aged children that
their children must attend school. On February 23rd, I
visited the Chief of the Sucker Creek Reserve and requested
his full co-operation in seeing that the parents having
children of school age be sent to school. The response has
been very satisfactory, not only from Sucker Creek but also
from Driftpile. Prior to Mr. Morris' visit there were 40
children, 27 from Driftpile and 13 from Sucker Creek who were
not attending school. To-date 35 of these children have been
returned, 23 from Driftpile and 12 from Sucker Creek. On
Saturday, March 2nd, I had the R.C.M.P. notify the parents of
the remaining five children of the consequences of truancy.
I feel confident the parents of these children will heed this
first notice and no further action will be found necessary.

Clerk, Indian Agency.

Dear Sir:

In reply to yours of July 11th, I beg to advise you that pupil No. 0269 was extern nearly all year, with the exception of thirty days in residence. Her Father asked me to take her for a month, while he was going far. She came here, on May 2nd, and returned home, June 5th.

As for No. 0308, She came April 11th, and left on June 4th, She had no reason to go, her father took her without my consent, saying as an excuse, that she was lonesome.

Your file 8Q-131.

Further to correspondence re the above, this is to advise that Mr. Lapp, Major C. A. F. Clark and I discussed this matter very fully with the principal of the Joussard Indian Residential School. The facts as already reported by Mr. Lapp and myself were found to be correct, except that the Indian families concerned are living on lands belonging to the R. C. Mission and not on Provincial lands. However, if some of the families living on the Sucker Creek Reserve were eventually to follow the example set by the Kakinocit family, they would more than likely take up residence on Provincial lands adjoining the Church land.

It was finally agreed that Mrs. Kakinocit's children would be accepted as day pupils at the Joussard Residential School provided that a grant on their behalf is authorized by the Education Division. This will also involve the acceptance of children of four other families living on the Church property.

The principal stated that no other families would be allowed to take up residence on their property. If other families follow suit and take up residence on Provincial lands next the school, their children must not be accepted at the Joussard Residential School on a day school basis.

If you concur in the decision reached, please advise. It will be necessary to make retroactive payment of Family Allowances on behalf of those children who attended the same school on the same basis last year, provided their attendance was regular.

Mr. Lapp will also have to supply the school with the necessary forms so that attendance of the day school pupils, when not regular, can be reported to the Regional Director of Family Allowances.

Major Clark has reported on this matter direct to Col. Neary.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Extract from a letter addressed to the Officer Commanding "G" Division, R.C.M.P. Police, Ottawa, dated the 29th of November, 1950, and signed by Insp. L.M. Lapointe, Fort Smith S/Division, Fort Smith, N.W.T.

Re: Phillipe Charles NORWEGIAN - Fort Smith, N.W.T.

2. Since his arrival at the Fort Smith Detachment, this boy has shown himself to be exceptionally bright and alert, and far above the usual Indian of his age (14). He is exceptionally clean about his clothing and person, baths practically every day, and takes pride in his appearance. He has also shown himself most willing in performing the chores and work allotted to him.

3. His formal education has been sadly neglected, through no fault of his own. All members of the Fort Smith detachment have taken a keen interest in the lad, and Cst. Coulter, who was a school teacher before joining the Force, has been teaching him for several hours each day in grade three subjects, assisted by the other detachment members.

4. The improvement in this boy's general attitude, etc., since coming here, has been amazing. In my opinion it would not be to his best interests to parole him at this time. I feel that his chances of ultimate rehabilitation would be greatly enhanced if he were left here at least until Spring, when, if he were returned to Fort Simpson, he could come under the continued guidance of our members. It would perhaps be better however, if he could be sent from here to a good Indian school rather than return to his home at Simpson. I feel that he has very good possibilities, if given the opportunity to make good.

5. I agree that the course suggested is a deviation from regular routine, and could not be followed in every such instance; however I feel in this case it is well worth while.
Dear Col. Neary:

Phillipe Charles Norwegian

The above noted Treaty Indian boy, born the 24th of December, 1935, was sentenced at Fort Simpson, N.W.T., on September 26, 1950, to serve one year at hard labour in the Fort Smith guard room of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police upon being convicted on two charges of breaking and entering and one charge of wilful damage.

The Juvenile Delinquents Act was not in force at Fort Simpson at the time and, therefore, the Stipendiary Magistrate had to deal with the case in accordance with the provisions of the Criminal Code of Canada. Attached is an extract from a report submitted by the Officer Commanding the Fort Smith Subdivision of the R.C.M.P. recommending that young Norwegian be paroled in the near future and that he be sent to an Indian school to further his education.

I understand that it might be possible to admit this boy to the Indian Residential school at Grouard, Alberta, and upon definite advice being received from you that he will be accepted in this or some other suitable institution, the matter of obtaining a remission of his sentence will be submitted.

Yours very truly,

Col. B.F. Neary,
Superintendent, Education Service,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration.
Ottawa, Ontario.

G.E.B. Sinclair
Director.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Re: Phillipe Charles Norwegian

I duly received your letter of the 10th instant, in which you inquire if it would not be possible to accept Phillipe Charles Norwegian in our school.

The conduct of this boy has certainly not been good in the past. However, he has much improved following a whole year spent under the supervision of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. Nevertheless, I am somewhat reluctant in accepting him in our school where all the boys are under 14 years of age, and consequently too young to come in contact with Phillipe Charles Norwegian who was 15 years old on December 24th last.

Everything is going smoothly presently in our school, and I would not want to see the peaceful atmosphere disrupted in any way by a newcomer.

Yours very sincerely,

High Prairie, Alta.,

With reference to the December Quarterly Return for the Joussard Indian Residential School the Department approves the discharge of pupils # 0313 and 0323.

With reference to the Return, it is noted that in many instances pupils were absent during the Quarter and in the Remarks Column the Principal indicated the dates during which these children were at home. From the information indicated in the Remarks Column, it would appear that in all instances the children were actually at home during the period indicated with the result that in almost all cases the Principal claimed two days more for each pupil than the grant to which the school was entitled. These children left the residence the day before the date indicated and returned the day following the date shown.

To avoid future errors of this nature, it is suggested that you advise the Principal that he should indicate in the Remarks Column the date the pupils left the residence and returned to school. In other words, his remarks should pertain to the actual attendance of the children in the school rather than their stay at home. This practice is followed by most of the Indian residential school Principals and this system has proved satisfactory. You may advise the Principal that the school is entitled to Per Capita Grant for the day the pupil left the residential school and the day the pupil returned to the school irrespective of whether a child leaves or enters the school in the morning or the afternoon.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Reference is made to your letter of January 14, 1953, file 762-10 (E6) in which you note that it appears that the Principal has claimed two days more for each pupil who was absent at home, than the grant to which the school was entitled.

Please refer to pupil No. 315, Orlin Giroux. The Remarks Column indicates that this child was sick at home from October 1st to 5th. Actually Orlin Giroux left the school on October 1st and returned to the school on October 5th, therefore the Principal has rightly claimed grant for October 1st and October 5th. Similarly, in other cases where the children were sick at home, during the quarter, the dates shown in the Remarks Column are the dates the children left the school and returned to the school. Report of Agnes Lawan, March 5th, 1936

Agnes Lawan of Seven Rivers was admitted to St. Bonne Residential School in February 17th, 1931 at the age of 6. Health was good at that time.

Child took whooping cough in December 1934. She never regained her former good health, and cough never cleared up entirely.

Began spitting blood in June 1935. Went home for two weeks vacation hoping the change would do her good, but returned in a more debilitated condition.

Sent to Sacred Heart Hospital McLean October 15th by train, and accompanied by Sister Peter Julian, R.N., who is at present at Nakasson.

In Gonzales.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Dear Sir,

Answering yours of the 22nd instant I beg to state that:

Miss Agnes Sowan female treaty Indian was admitted in the Sacred Hospital at McLennan Alta on the 18th of October 1925 and that she died on the 21st of the same month from tuberculosis of the lungs.

Age 9 years old; T.B. predisposed by birth; probably specific.

The patient was coughing and spitting blood since June 1935.

The 3rd week of October 1925 the patient getting worst, is brought to the hospital on the 18th of October 1925 after having had a serious haemoptysis the day before.

Examination: Temp. 99 2/5 Pulse 120 Resp. 24 rate dyspnea. General appearance very poor, patient much underweight. Both lungs bases and top, mottled and crepitant, acute congestion on clio superiorly of both lungs.

Heart: (Suffles à la pointe) bruit de gallop, acute myocarditis.

Treatment: Patient put to bed at complete rest. Milk diet. Antiflugistine pustules on chest, camphor in oil. Stokes mixture. Adrenaline in need. Surajimination (milk only). Aeration and fresh air.

Patient rest till 3 o'clock p.m. on the 18th when she had a severe haemorrhage of the lungs. Ice cap on chest. Adrenaline, patient recovers and rests. 19th, pt... rest till 5 a.m. then very severe haemorrhage again. Condition very poor. Pulse 140 Temp. (96 2/5) Heart in acute tachycardia and irregular. Pt... recover again but very weak.

The 20th. Respiration rapid and irregular. Pt... slept at long intervals in the daytime and had a better night.

The 21st. General A.M. cares camphor in oil. # # # # # # / # # # # / ice cap on chest. Cough mixture. Olive oil on chest etc. Pt.... had a fair day Gen. evening cares Pt... resting well till 9 35 o'clock, Pt... begin to cough, severe recurrent haemoptysis. Dear Sir,

You may perhaps remember the conversation we had in your office in May last, when you kindly volunteered to interest yourself with the Government in behalf of our Indian Home among the Piegans.

The Indian Department has granted four hundred dollars towards the buildings; but this is a very small sum for such an extensive and very expensive project—so we wish to bring before the Government, the desirability of further assistance in order to make it a thorough success.

For some time we were led to expect the Department would assist us very considerably in this Boarding School & Home; but the negotiations ended in a four hundred dollar grant for the building and ration of beef & flour for twelve pupils.

We now ask the Department for a further grant of $600 so as to clear the building of debt and a grant $60 per head per ann., for six pupils, with full ration of beef & flour for six only also to break up a fence, five acres for...
situation, & will look very well when finished.

This matter of Government aid remains to a great extent in your hands; I feel sure you will do all you can for us, in thus helping us in this good work of evangelizing these wild benighted heathen and making them a useful, loyal, & self-supporting people.

My dear Mr. Dewdney,

The enclosed memorandum was sent to me last November by the Rev. Mr. Brown, the Chief of the Presbyterian Missionary at Fort Macleod. I wrote to him today, that I did not think I could do too much by writing, but that when the session began, I would take an opportunity of speaking to you on the subject.

I placed this letter among a number of other papers.
which I brought down with me when the Session began, and I was ashamed that I entirely overlooked it, and was only reminded of it by another letter received from Mr. Brown yesterday.

Can you give him any hope or encouragement? I know him personally, and I can testify that he and his wife are both most earnest self-denying people whose hearts are thoroughly in their work—I feel none vexed than I can let go at my negligence, and should hardly forgive myself if this delay has made it more difficult to meet his wishes. Sept. 22nd, 1890.

Sir:

Mr. Bourne called to see me today with regard to his boarding school, and requested me to inform you that he is not prepared to carry on the school unless increased aid is given to him by the Department. He states that he is running into debt himself, over expenses connected with the school, and that he cannot go on, that he was led to believe by the Department, before starting in, that he would receive from them $50.00 a year for each pupil in addition to their rations.

He explained to me that he receives no aid whatsoever from the Bishop of the diocese, and, outside of what the Department allows, all he gets is from charitable friends down East, some $100.00 a year and gifts of clothing &c. There is a debt he tells me yet of $270.00 on the building.

Feign Christmas Tree.

To the Editor Gazette,

Dear Sir,—The following little bit of news I should like to communicate to your readers at this juncture. On New Year's Eve we gave our boys and girls (numbering 36) Christmas tree. The tree was very tastefully decorated by the principal and staff of the House, with the toys and candy so kindly given by the merchants and friends in Macleod and Pincher Creek. In the earlier part of the day there had been seen Indian wagons coming along with a family and their blankets and the Indians themselves, the chief and the young Indian on his best horse, all making for the one spot, the Victoria House, where always the most welcome and hearty meal is down to feed, potatoes, plum pudding and tea which they seemed highly to appreciate. The large log dormitory was lighted up and a big spruce tree larger than ever was put in position and decorated. After the seats for the parents and friends and children were arranged, the children sang some of their songs in English which much pleased the parents. Then the boys, according to their good behavior, were allowed to choose from the tree what they would like, each having besides a box of candy to give them. The behaviour of the parents and children under the distribution of the presents if the tree was excellent and gold and it is a plain fact that, though the Indians are aborigines, the Indians of the west have never been discouraging, yes, you make a span here and there where the way of the unselfishness and kindness of man been missing, yet surely, driving out the old ways. A very noticeable fact was that not one of the men was stripped of his coat and hat but rather the white man ways they are taking to, even so far coats, high boots and ties. I am obliged to the principal and staff wish to thank those merchants and friends of Macleod and Pincher Creek for their kindness to the children and help which makes it so easy to give the Indians and children on the Feign Reserve, so happy a time at that season of the year.

E. Hillier

I have the honour to report for your information that on January the 7th, 1899 the boys of this institution were dressed as usual to go out to play, and were warned not to go near the hill about one hundred (100) yards from the back of the institution. They had scarcely been out of the house fifteen minutes (15) when one of them came running in, and said some of the boys were buried under the snow. We at once went to the scene and found that the snow on the side of the hill had slid down. Two of the boys were visible, these we at once set to work to dig out, one of them was buried up to the waist, and the other to the chin, finding there were still two missing, we at once got assistance from a rancher who resides close by, and sent for the Indians. We found one of the boys about twenty minutes past eleven (11.20) but life was extinct, but the second was not found until about fifteen minutes to one (15.1) who was also quite dead.

The parents of the dead boys arrived and a very sad sight it was to see them beside their dear boys.

We sent to Pincher Creek for the Coroner, but there was none appointed to that position, but Mr. Morden J.P. said that an inquest was not necessary. A member of the North West Mounted Police came over and saw the bodies, and the place where the accident occurred. The bodies remained here.

INDIAN BOYS KILLED.

Pupils of the Piegans Indian Boarding School Killed by a Snowslide.

The Indian department has received word of the death of two Indian children killed in a snowslide at the boarding school on the Piegans Reserve near Calgary. The snowslide occurred on Jan. 7. During recess some of the boys were playing on a hill about three hundred yards behind the school. This hill was covered to the top with snow although there had been prohibitions. They had not been going down the hill but when some pupils ran into the school saying several boys were missing they knew something was wrong. The members of the staff ran out and discovered that while the snowslide had occurred, because of the depth of snow which apparently frequently happens in the spring, the pupils could be seen buried in the snow at the bottom of the hill. One boy was buried up to the waist and the other to the neck, and both were killed instantly. Two pupils were still missing and an attempt was made to rescue them. One was found after an hour and another in two hours. Both had been killed before they were found. The parents of the children were summoned and arrangements were made for their removal. It is understood the Indians do not blame the white authorities and that they have warned the children against going near the hill. The school is located on a river creek and was notched but did not think an attempt would be made to cross it. The boys killed were John Brightmore, aged nine, and Frank Brightmore, aged ten. The hill is about sixty feet high and the snowslide carried down the snow for 300 feet along its face.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Mrs. Green, Dorcas Secretary of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Diocese of Ottawa, who was a delegate to the Conference of the Auxiliary in Vancouver, visited some of the Church of England schools on her return trip, and has written the Department, soliciting a grant of sufficient money to purchase a pair of horses for the Peigan Boarding School.

From reports on file this is the most successful Church of England Boarding School in the West, and the Rev. Mr. Haynes, who is the Principal, is wielding a good influence over the Indians of the Peigan reserve. (See Mr. Inspector Markle's report on No. 6 of this file.)

Dr. Bryce, in giving his impressions of this school says:

"The whole history of this school, with limited funds and as found at present, efficient and free from any debt, shows what a devoted Missionary may accomplish. The Agent states that it is especially the Indians surrounding the Mission, which under Mr. Haynes' influence have proved most moral and progressive. He has succeeded in getting them to erect better houses, and their superior character is manifest. A number have enclosed spaces of prairie and begun farming in earnest."

Sir,

During my visit to the Peigan reserve, Alberta, I went over the C. of E. Indian Boarding school building. I beg to call your attention to a few of the conditions which I found.

My first impression was that the location is decidedly bad. The building is situated near a creek, and on very low ground. I was told that the overflow in the spring flooded the land at the rear of the building and left an offensive sediment. The ground was very soggy and wet the day I was there but a new fall of snow covered a great deal from sight. I had to pick my way around, however, in order to keep dry.

The hills immediately at the rear of the building are productive of a great deal of dust at such times as the wind blows in the summer. The waste water is dumped at the rear of the building and the refuse thrown into a creek bottom whence it is expected to be washed away in the spring floods. I do not think that any building in this location could be kept clean. Certainly the place is a breeding place for flies, and in the building there were evidences of a great many.

School is conducted in the laundry annex. It is necessary to pass through the kitchen in order to enter the classroom. When I entered the school room the largest boy in the class was sprawled full length on the floor beside the stove. The floor was far from being clean. I noticed that the teacher had, what I considered, a poor method of teaching. She goes from one desk to another and squats down beside the pupils.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6369, file 763-1, part 1)
to instruct them. Her desk, a very dilapidated old table, was piled high with old books etc. and showed no signs of use as a desk. It was also very dusty. The walls of the room had apparently been repaired but were already getting in bad shape again. The children, with the exception of two girls, were very poorly clad and their clothes were dirty. Two of the boys were at work on the wood pile, (during school hours). Principal Fisher took me through the rest of the building. The kitchen floor had two large pools of water on it, one at the pump and the other an overflow from the waste water can. The floor was dirty as also the walls. I did not care to stop long in this part. There are two dining rooms, one for the pupils and another for the staff. The pupils' dining room was far from inviting while the staff dining room, which one might expect to be a model, was very untidy. The boys' playroom was very dirty and the walls were in bad shape. I was informed that the floor had been lately painted, but the only signs of paint that I could see were in the cracks.

In the dormitories, upstairs, conditions were very little better. In the open air dormitories, which are not used during the cold weather, there were a great many dead or stupified flies on the floor. The dust from the hills previously referred to was greatly in evidence.

It is not a pleasant duty to place on record such an unfavorable report of conditions in an institution to which the department looks for the education and improvement of Indian children. Success along this line must be the result of first, example, and secondly, instruction. Certainly I could see no commendable example at this place. If I am obliged to say that the personnel of the staff afforded no very uplifting example.
example, I am at once inclined to refrain from laying too much blame on the staff as this may be due to insufficiency of staff. I am constrained to say, however, that this institution is in no way a credit to the department nor those who are running it, and I fail to see in what way it can be of any benefit to our Indian pupils so long as it is run as at present. The building, however, is in too bad condition to warrant any very extensive repairs or improvements. The best that could be done would be to close it for such time as would be required to thoroughly clean it and disinfect it.

In the event of a new building being contemplated I would urge that the department insist on a better location. It would be a grave mistake to continue the use of this location for school purposes. No building could possibly be kept clean in this location. I think that a cesspool of some kind should be built as soon as possible. There is on file a report from the medical officer on this school and I can bear him out in all he says. I do not think that there is any malice shown in his report. Looking at the conditions from a medical man's standpoint, I am surprised that his report is not stronger than it is.

I would like to add that I also visited the cottage hospital, where nine of the pupils have been under treatment. This was certainly a bright spot after the school building. The nurse in charge has the building spotlessly clean. She scrubs it all over, as well as washing the beds every morning. The patients were all doing well. The condition of the hospital was, in every way, all that could be desired. I could find nothing that I would wish different. When it
is considered that the nurse has done night and day duty without relief ever since taking charge, I think that she deserves every credit. Certainly here was a shining example for the children which they would never get at the school. I noticed a great difference in the discipline also. There was no doubt as to who was in charge.

I have the honor to be,

As far back as 1913 the attention of the Department was drawn to the inefficient administration of the Church of England Boarding School, on the Peigan Reserve. I must enclose herewith expense account with receipts for the move from John Smith's Reserve.

I may say that on the 29th July, I received a communication from the M.S.O.C. saying that they were not prepared to appoint a man to Gleichen, but that this place was without a man in charge and it was desired that proceed here.

I consulted with C.M.R. freight Agent in Prince Albert and found that a direct shipment of goods here was cheaper than making a shipment from Prince Albert to Calgary, and then on again either to this place or to Gleichen.

If the M.S.O.C. require me to go to Gleichen, I will of course do so at my own expense.

On the 28th of July I spoke to Agent Schmidt over the telephone, and in response to his enquiry as to when I would be leaving; he took it for granted that I was leaving. I told him that I wanted to get away by the afternoon 31st and he informed me that he would come down on the 29th and check over the Department property, but he failed to put in an appearance up till 2 o'clock of the 31st. All the Department property was checked and in its place, and everything left in order, and the keys of the building given to Albert Bear, M.E., and Agent Schmidt notified by postcard.

The Department do not owe the John Smith's Indians any accounts. I paid Mrs. Adam Charles for assisting me for months of May and June and sent Agent Schmidt the receipt for same asking cheque to be made to me, but same has not reached me, I will inquire of Agent Schmidt for this ashe will be aware of the circumstances.

My overseers cheque and matron's cheque for month of July has not been received. I surmise I may expect these at an early date.

I am really sorry that you could not personally see the outfit we left, and what we have come into. We left a tidy order, clean, and well kept. This is filthy, disgracefully dirty, badly arranged and I should say poorly looked after in the past. The children are away in a camp for a holiday for a few days, which will give us an opportunity to set fixed a little. I have never come into such a disgraceful place as regards dirt.

However we are coming in with a new staff with the exception of the outside man, and changes for the better could be managed without difficulty.

I must ask you to excuse the watered ink and many subjects in one letter. Our household goods have not reached Brocket. There is no offce material and things are more or less muddled. I will call at the Agency and see if it is possible to get the account into the typewriter.

Yours very truly,

Sir—

I beg to submit the following report in connection with the Victoria Home Co-op Boarding School at Brocket.

There has been some friction between this office and the Principal of this school over incorrect returns sent in by him to be forwarded to the Department. As these returns have not yet been revised I am unable to forward them to the Bena Department. This school has never before caused this office one tenth part of the trouble we are now experiencing as the frequent and persistent absconding of pupils has become invererate at this institution since the Rev. Mr Middleton was appointed Principal. The attitude taken by Mr Middleton and his assistant seems to be that they are in no way responsible, and have not to bother about these boys running away from the school, and that this matter is the concern of this office only. The requests for the return of absentees from this school have been so frequent since Mr Middleton took charge that this staff having their own duties to perform had not the time to be continually on the road after these truants. This being the case I asked Mr Middleton to come to the office or his assistant to make out information forms so that I could issue a warrant to the R.C.M. Police for the return of these boys. This he did for quite some time and the boys were returned by the police much more speedily than this staff could have done on account of our Indians being scattered all over the country working at the outside threshing. However since I refused to certify to incorrect returns for him, he has refused to make out information in the proper manner and therefore preventing me from issuing warrants to the police without which they will not act, this is pure peevishness and quite obvious to any one. My request that the school authorities come here and make out information forms is reasonable and necessary as a warrant cannot be issued.
without this form first being made out and as this is only the work of a minute it can in no way work a hardship on the school authorities and would also facilitate the return of the boys although I doubt very much if this will prevent the desertions from this school which I am afraid under the present management will be of frequent occurrence. There seems to be an utter lack of sympathy for the boys on the part of the Principal and his assistant as the following incident will show. Two of the boys who had run away from school returned on Monday the 8th inst., it was during the dinner hour and they were not even asked to share the meal with the other children; the Principal or his assistant never took these boys in charge in fact as far as my information goes they were utterly ignored. One boy was let go home again with his guardian and the other boy simply walked out of the school to the camp again. This to me is absurd and past all understanding a school cannot be run along these lines with any hope of success amongst Indians. It seems to me that it was the duty of the Principal or his assistant to interview these boys at that time. Just another instance of the absurd way in which things are run at this school. A few weeks ago an Indian named Crow Shoe returned his boy to the school, on meeting the assistant Principal he told him that he had brought his boy back but that the Agent had said that the boy was not to be whipped, this was not true, but I suppose that the Indian was anxious about his boy, the assistant Principal immediately told him to take his boy away this boy has not returned to the school. This sort of thing is amazing? I met Bishop Pinkham during his recent visit to this reserve and talked this matter over with him in presence of the C of E Missionary and the agency clerk and His Lordship agreed with me that I had asked Mr Middle- tom nothing but what was reasonable in regard to the school matters.

I enclose herewith a letter from the Corporal in charge of the R.C.M. Police stationed on this reserve which speaks for itself, and will show the Department just what amount of extra work this school is causing and how absolutely impossible it would be for this staff to manage all this running around after deserters from Mr Middletons School. Will the Department in view of the facts which I have laid before them, issue instructions to the Principal of the C of E School here, that when this office asks him to come and make out information forms that he is expected to do so, as it is impossible for me to issue warrants to the police for these boys.

Dear Canon Gould:

Relative to the question of attendance at the above School.

Since your departure, and until Wednesday the 17th, inst., none of the absentees had been returned to the School, but in the meantime seven more had deserted, thus leaving the School almost destitute of boys.

In order to have them speedily returned, I followed out most minutely the instructions as sent me by the Indian Department, and repeatedly asked for the co-operation of the Indian Agent in affecting their return. This was apparently refused, for in two specific cases he requested the people with whom the pupils were staying to keep them around camp for a few days. One of these two boys stayed in Mr. Haynes' house for three successive nights, and the Missionary then started a report amongst the Indians that the boy was so filthy and dirty that he had to provide him with a change of clothing, asserting that was the reason the boy left the School. I might state here that this same boy had been absent from the School eleven days prior to his visit to the Mission House, (of which fact Mr. Haynes was quite aware), and during that time had slept in several Indian houses and in hay stacks, and had not taken off his clothing since leaving School.
The Missionary has also during the past week been soliciting complaints about the School from a neighboring rancher, but asking that his name might not be mentioned. Needless to say, such conduct met, (in this case) with a well deserved rebuke. The inference is obvious.

Seeing that the Indian Agent at Brocket was openly defying constituted authority by allowing the deserters to habitually frequent the camp around the Agency, (he informed Mr. Heron that the Indians had refused to send the absentees back) I thereupon called to see the Officer Commanding the R.C.M.P. at Barracks at Macleod, and asked if he would kindly instruct his man at Brocket - Stevens - to apprehend and return the pupils to School.

This he promptly did, for nine boys were brought back yesterday by Corporal Stevens, who stated that the balance would be rounded up and returned during the next few days.

I called upon the Indian Agent and read, and also left him a copy of the letter containing your conclusions dealing with the deserters. On a subsequent visit of Mr. Heron to the Office, Mr. Graham indignantly handed the letter to him, stating that "Canon Gould's opinion carries no weight with me, as I receive my orders from the Department".

I trust that you will pardon this bald statement of facts. This is not being sent as a complaint, but simply to place before you the recent developments in order that you may be thoroughly conversant with the main events.

The points at issue are these:

1. Is the School to be the loser of the grant of the absentees?
2. Is the tone and discipline of the Institution to be demoralized by the insidious influence of outside sources?
3. The improbability of obtaining new pupils under such conditions.
In view of adequate provision being made for a full attendance, and the apparent laxity, opposition, and negligence displayed by those in authority, would strongly recommend that a ruling be sought from the Department in order that the esprit de corps and finances of the School may be safe-guarded.

Thanking you for your past assistance, and earnestly hoping for a continued support in this problem,

Yours obedient servant,
(Sgd) S.H.Middleton,
Principal.

Dear Mr. Middleton,

I have learned with very great regret that, following my visit, two more boys, "George" and "Sam", have deserted from the Peigan Boarding School.

I have, since my visit, to the School, given a great deal of thought to the situation. I am persuaded that no just cause exists in the School itself for the desertions in question, and for those which preceded them. The children are well fed, clothed, and cared for. The discipline, while strict, has not been greater than the conditions required, while the physical punishments have been of the regulation type which are inflicted in all our schools for white children.

Under these circumstances it is, in my opinion, your duty to call upon the local Officers of the Department of Indian Affairs to exert their full influence and authority under the regulations of the Department, in returning the pupils who have deserted, to the School, and keeping them there. I do not include in this statement the two older lads, since I am very doubtful of the wisdom of retaining them in school.

I hope to pay an early visit to Ottawa, and will then discuss the whole situation personally with the Deputy Inspector General for Indian Affairs. I will also take up with him the cases of the two "older lads" under discussion, and desire in consequence that you take no further steps, in the meanwhile, concerning them.

You are at liberty, if you so desire, to show this letter to the local Official of the Indian Department, as containing my conclusions after giving the situation my very careful consideration.
