Dear Mr. Scott:

In accordance with your wish I beg, herewith, to place in writing the chief points discussed in our conversation of yesterday.

1. The Peigan Boarding School:
On the occasion of my recent visit, October 25th, to this School, I found awaiting me, on arrival, a note from Mr. Graham, the Indian Agent, making request that I call to see him. This I did, about 9:00 a.m. in his office, and thus discussed with him certain matters in connection with the School, prior to talking them over with either the Principal of the School or the Missionary on the Reserve.

I subsequently had conversations with the Principal of the School, with the resident master, with the missionary on the Reserve, with the local officer of...
the Mounted Police, and also had a "pow-wow" in the evening with about fifteen Indians.

My first visit to this School was made two or three years ago when we were making preliminary investigations with a view to the taking over by the M.S.C.C., from the several dioceses concerned, of full and direct responsibility for the Indian work.

At that time, I was deeply impressed with the prevailing unsatisfactory conditions. I found, for example, two of the older boys chained together as a punishment for desertion, taking with them the school team and rig. I found other conditions which I described to you, in brief, yesterday. The missionary was then in charge with an Assistant Principal in residence.

Our Executive Committee, as soon as possible after taking over responsibility for the School, endeavoured to put an end to this condition of affairs by appointing the Rev. S.W. Middleton, Principal of the Blood School, Acting Principal, also, of the Peigan School; with a resident master, Mr. Heron, in direct charge.

The immediate results were apparently very good. Discipline was asserted and a Cadet Corp organized, followed by a successful Field Day held by the united Cadet Corps of the Blood and Peigan Schools.

The elder girls also were taken, along with those of the Blood School, for a month's holiday to the very
satisfactory summer camp held on this Society's leased property at the Waterton Lakes. I visited Waterton Lakes, I may add, and found it a delightful spot. Our Executive Committee, on my recommendation, has voted the money needed, for the erection there next spring, of an enlarged and satisfactory girls dormitory.

On my recent visit, in view of the conflicting statements given me, concerning severity of discipline, I paid particular attention to the bearing of the children in the School, especially the boys, and came to the conclusion that their free and easy conduct conveyed no impression of "terrorism", on the part of those in charge. I noticed, for example, the fact that although the Principal, the Resident Master, and I were in an adjoining room, with only a thin partition between, the boys formed up in their play room and headed by a "mouth organist", more vigorous than musical, marched around the room. Boys, who are treated with undue harshness, do not, I submit, engage spontaneously in such "antics" in the very near neighborhood of their masters.

Following the summer holidays, two of the larger boys who have given repeated trouble failed to return, and their example was apparently, to some extent, responsible for the repeated desertions which have, since, taken place.

The causes of these desertions are to be sought, I am persuaded, more in influences which exist outside the School than in conditions which are to be found within its walls. One of the boys I understand, for example, deserted
the night following his "birthday party" which had been held in the School in his honour.

The "outside conditions" in question must, I believe, be faced and overcome, and they must be overcome through the co-operation of the authorities of the Indian Department and of the Missionary Society in insisting that all the local agents of both shall submerge personal antipathies and work together in loyal co-operation for the success of the School.

I enclose copies of:

(1) My letters, dated Oct. 29th, and Oct. 30th, written to the Principal prior to my return from the West.

(2) The Principal's letters to me, dated Nov. 8th, 9th, and 20th, and received this morning.

In conclusion there is no question in my mind but that the two boys, Joe Warrior and Bert Stripped Squirrel, are incorrigible, and that they should be brought back to the School and then formally and publicly dismissed. As for the others, there is no way open before us, if the old methods of "incarceration" and "chaining up" are to be forever eradicated, as they have and must continue to be, than to insist that every deserter shall be brought back every time he deserts and be given such "regulation type" of punishment as his offence demands. In this way only, I am certain, can the boys, the parents, and all others concerned be convinced that petty intrigue and wholesale desertion will not be tolerated as the local expression of dissatisfaction with the means adopted by those responsible.
to end an intolerable condition of indiscipline and, as a first step in the rather long task of placing the School upon a basis satisfactory alike to the authorities of the Department of Indian Affairs and of the Missionary Society.

In view of the conditions described there is, I think, much force in Mr. Middleton's contentions with regard to grants, etc., as outlined in the final paragraph of his letter dated November 20th.

In view of the great, but necessary, length of this letter, I reserve the discussion of the "other points" for a further communication.

Believe me,

Chaos and laxity reigned supreme.

It is due to the enforcement of regular order and a system of real School Life which I insist upon carried out, that has been responsible for the desertions in question.

The pupils, not being accustomed to a systematized scheme of routine, and being under other influences, rebelled against the training given. I made a fairly thorough examination of your school today, and beg to report as follows:

Grade III coming on strongly in reading and arithmetic. It is now at the stage where it must broaden out in its reading to enrich its intelligence.

Grade II is also up to standard or rather above standard considering that the two pupils are only six and seven years old.

Grade IV is rather weak all round, and Grade V. only one pupil is barely average.

Grade VI. two pupils are doing exceedingly well giving a brilliant review in history and geography, showing a good grasp of arithmetic and displaying excellent work in their exercise books. The average of Grade VIII. was also good though the pupils differ considerably in ability. Their exercise books were also excellent.

Mr. Giggle displays the same thoroughness and careful organization of his work that I noted in my last report. You have a very superior teacher in Mr. Giggle.

The worst conditions in an Indian residential school that I encountered on my 1 months' tour were found in this institution. The building is old and in a dilapidated condition. The number of pupils enrolled was 31. The evidences as to the class-room work were most discouraging. The dormitory accommodation was poor. Mattresses were apparently unknown; folded quilts were used. The milk supply for a total of 37 in the institution was limited to one cow. I spoke to the Principal regarding this and he stated that he had asked for more stock, but that he had not heard from Rev. Dr. Westgate, of Winnipeg. The health of the children was rather poor, and the Agent and others believe that a hospital is needed in this Agency.

Re: JACK CROW SNEE - Loitering in a public place by night and not giving a good account of himself. Contrary to Sect. 238 C.C. of C.

On the 14th inst., Mr. Giggles, Principal of the C. of E. Indian Boarding School of Brocket, complained to Const Giles, that some of the ex-pupils were hanging around the school at night trying to get into the girls' dormitory.

Const Giles and Scout Smith patrolled that night to the school and caught the above Indian, together with another, about 12 o'clock, hanging around outside the buildings.

On being questioned they had no reasons for being there but said they wanted to see the girls.

I phoned to the Provincial Police at Pincher Creek, but, owing to sickness he could not handle the case and I got Magistrate Gresham from Blairmore to come down and hear the case.

A short time ago the Principle of the C.of E. School here laid a complaint against four young Indians for entering the girls dormitory of the school.

Dear Sir,

No irregularities, unsatisfactory condition etc., at the above School, contained in your letter of the 9th inst., the undermentioned report, taken from my Diary will, I think, cover the whole of the circumstances:

1924.
April 29. Had suspicions something was going wrong in the School amongst the girls. Mrs. Roe instituted a search this afternoon, and found letters and bunch of keys in mattress of Annie Bull Pen. Had the letters incriminated 4 ex-pupils: Joe Warrior, Jackie Crowshoe, Samson Knowlton and Jim Morning Bull. Did not question the girls today with reference to contents of letters.

May 3. Took letters and keys to Mr. Arthur (Indian Agent) this morning, and we, Mr. Arthur and myself, agreed it was high time something drastic was done to stop the continual nuisance of these ex-pupils.

The A.M. Penisher Creek was advised by Mr. Arthur in my presence by phone, and agreed to come in and arrest the four ex-pupils on the following morning—May 1st. Mrs. Roe found another bunch of keys, with two skeleton keys on which had evidently been supplied by the ex-pupils. Annie Bull Pen, Mary One Owl, Elizabeth and Lizzie broke away from Miss Hadden (Girls' Supervisor) whilst at exercise in School grounds. Search was made by Mr. Barlow and myself without success.

May 1. Mr. Arthur rang me up on phone, and told me he should have to report the matter. I told him it was his duty to do so, so that things could be remedied, and the long delayed necessary equipment be furnished to prevent a recurrence of the trouble. However, on reaching the Agency this morning, Mr. Arthur failed to repeat what he said over the phone, and was apparently in accord with me that the ex-pupils should be charged, and that a salutary punishment should be inflicted.

On my going round the Reserve with Mr. Arthur, to try and locate Joe Warrior, Mr. Arthur said that Johnnie Crow Eagle—a Minor Chief had told him three weeks previously that these young men were breaking into the School. Mr. Arthur failed to advise me a gross neglect of duty, and amounting to connivance.

During the drive Mr. Arthur and I stopped and spoke to Jim Morning Bull's father and Willie Knowlton. Mr. Arthur informed Willie Knowlton that the prosecuting of the 4 ex-pupils was not his doing, inferring that he would not have taken proceedings, and also to blacken me in the eyes of the Indians.

All 4 young men arrested by Constable Gauzy, A.P.P., today, and lodged in Pincher.

Four girls located at May Big Bull's, and brought home in Mr. Lancaster's car, by Mr. Lancaster and myself.

May 2. About 10.30 a.m., Mr. Lancaster phoned me from the Agency to say he would be down shortly to take me to Pincher—came coming before the stipendiary Mr. Graham. Mr. Arthur's attitude towards me in the waiting room of the Court anything but that of a gentleman. His solicitor, Mr. Jackson, whom I had not the faintest knowledge he was employing, and why engaged...
I do not know, seeing that we were agreed in asking only for such punishment as would act as a deterrent. There was some difficulty prior to opening of Court as what charge to bring against defendants. Apparently that of vagrancy was agreed upon both by police Mr. Arthur and myself, and upon this charge the defendants were sentenced to six weeks at Blairmore.

On the plea of Samson Knowlton being a subject, plea made by Mr. Arthur. Mr. Gresham, the Magistrate, made comment that Knowlton appeared to be the strongest of the 4 defendants. Knowlton was let out on suspended sentence, Tom Big Smoke and Willie Crowshoe becoming bondsmen for him.

Mr. Arthur, on making his statement in Court, stated that he considered there was great laxity on the part of the Government and staff of the School. To this remark I begged the indulgence of the Magistrate, telling him I took strong exception to the criticism of Mr. Arthur in Court, and in making his criticism, he was not only exceeding his authority, but making remarks not relevant to the case.

His Worship nodded apparent consent to my objection, but made no comment, seeing that I was not legally represented.

Outside the Court, after the case was over, Mr. Arthur called out to me, so that Sergeant Duncan and Constable Ousey could hear "Summon your staff at 10 a.m., tomorrow Saturday morning, as I shall be down to make an investigation at the School."

May 3rd. Mr. Arthur visited the School this morning, accompanied by Mr. Lancaster, his clerk. It was some time before anything bearing upon the previous day's case was brought up.

I asked Mr. Arthur if he had known, or rather had been informed by Johnnie Crow Eagle, a Minor Chief three weeks ago, about these ex-pupils breaking into the School, why he had not made it his business to inform me. His excuse was, that the Indians bring him so many tales, he did not place any credence in it.

I also asked him his reason for exercising himself to Willie Knowlton, saying that it was not he (Mr. Arthur) that was prosecuting, to which Mr. Arthur vaguely replied he "meant what he said."

It was agreed in the presence of Mr. Lancaster that the staff of the School had exercised reasonable vigilance, and that it would require the employment of a night-watchman to prevent a recurrence.

At Mr. Arthur's suggestion, wire frames should be fixed to both Girls and Boys Dormitories, and he asked me to supply him with measurements. These were forwarded to the Agency on May 6th.

The subject of Electrical connexion with the Matron's rooms adjoining the dormitories was also gone into, and Mr. Arthur promised to get advice on the matter.

This terminated the investigation, not any members of the staff being present.

As apparently no attempt has been made up to the time of writing June 12th to provide the school with these necessary wire frames for the dormitories, I should be glad if you would kindly take the matter up with the Indian Dept.

Yours faithfully,

"G. A. ROE."

Dear Doctor Westgate:

Enclosed you will please find my Report on the alleged "Irregularities As" preferred by Mr. Arthur against myself and the staff of the School.

The Report itself is an exact copy of the events as recorded in my diary, and I think cover the whole of the ground; also there is not a thing mentioned in either Report or this covering letter but what can be substantiated.

From the beginning of my career here, it was evident to me that, judging by Mr. Arthur's conversation, he had very little use for our school, and that his sympathies were entirely with the R.C.S. School on this Reserve. All the virtues were centred in the R.C.S. and the vices contained in our School.

Invariably, on Mr. Arthur's visits to this School, he would tell me that the days of the Anglican School here were numbered, even going so far as to approximate the time - 5 years - when the school would be deserted. He has not only made this observation to me, but is also priming the Indians on the Reserve with it, and they have come and told me.

As recently as last December, Mr. Arthur had these same 4 ex-pupils and another before him at the Agency - three complaints made by me, for committing the same offence, that of breaking into the school, and he told me he had held a Court and placed them on suspended sentence. These ex-pupils apparently regarded their sentence in a very light manner, and the pending complaints made by me to the agent subsequent to their sentence, no steps were taken by him to end the nuisance. They were continually hanging around the school, and making themselves a source of annoyance and worry. I might add that 3 out of the 4 defendants had previous convictions against them.

Constable Gaussey, A.F.P., Pincher Creek, the officer who had charge of the case, and an entire stranger to me, asked me on the first day I met him "What kick has the Indian Agent against your School?" showing to what length Mr. Arthur had allowed his feelings to run.

I have evidence that, on the occasion of the Court proceedings at Pincher Creek, against two young Indians charged with breaking into Mr. Haynes' house, during his absence at the Coast, Mr. Arthur was the worse for drink, and he was under the influence of it at the Court I attended.

These two recent Court cases are sufficient to show the state of affairs on this Reserve. There is next to no police supervision beyond a weekly visit by the A.F.P. from Pincher; the rest of the week the Reserve is left to its own resources.

There should have been no difficulty in Mr. Arthur being able to end the nuisance, had he have wished, seeing that the School is off the Reserve. I found the only way to end the business, was by taking action myself.

As regards Mr. Arthur's desire to have me removed, and a stronger man appointed in my place, I would suggest that it is a weaker man he wants, and one that would swoop on his intrigues and play into his hands. I have no hesitation in saying that as long as Mr. Arthur is Agent here, our School will never get that measure of justice and equity which it has a right to demand and expect from the person holding the position of Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of June 4 (No.116-1-1) and my replies, with enclosures, dated June 9 and 17 respectively, relative to certain conditions at our Peigan School, as reported to you by Mr. Indian Agent Arthur of the Peigan Agency, I now beg to state that the Indian and Eskimo Commission of our Society have given full and careful attention to this whole question, and have instructed me to submit to you their conclusions as follows:

1. With regard to the statement which your letter contains, namely, "There has apparently been, at night, a lack of supervision on the part of the school staff," they beg to state that they are unable to find any evidence whatever which might be accepted in support of this opinion. The Boys' Supervisor at this school, Miss Gregory, of Toronto, who happened to be passing through Winnipeg on June 16, on her way home on short leave of absence, was carefully interrogated on this point, and asked to furnish the Commission with a written statement. The written statement furnished declares, in part, as follows:

"I am Boys' Matron at the Victoria Home on the Peigan Reserve, and my opinion about the trouble which has happened is, that it is not due to any neglect whatsoever on the part of the Principal or the staff. The ex-pupils who caused all this trouble have been trying to do the same thing ever since I have been there. The Principal has had a lot to contend with from them: not only through..."
their coming round the school, but through their sauciness to him.... The only way he could get protection was by taking the steps he did, and he was quite justified in doing so.... The Principal and the Farm Instructor have been out night after night through the ex-pupils trying to get into the school...."

In addition to the above statements, which our Commission have every reason to believe are fully correct, they are further confirmed in their opinion that there was no lack either of vigilance or of careful supervision on the part of the school's staff, by the uniformly good discipline maintained and progress made since Mr. Roe has been in charge. At the Regina Exhibition last year they carried off more prizes than any other Indian School, except one, which exhibited Indian School work, and information to this effect was conveyed to the Superintendent of Indian Education in a cutting from the Calgary Herald, enclosed in my letter of September 6th last.

When the utterly inadequate facilities which the main school building provides in the way of space, equipment, modern conveniences, &c., are taken into consideration, our Commission believe that Mr. Roe and his staff have accomplished a work that no other school of the same class has excelled, and are to be highly commended for it.

2. With regard to your request that I should recommend what action should be taken to safeguard this institution from future trouble, I beg to state that, in the opinion of our Commission, the most reliable safeguard against the recurrence of a trouble similar to the one in question, is to be found, not in the provision of electric alarm bells or wire frames for windows, but in a close and sympathetic co-operation between the Indian Agent and the Principal. That this does not exist at present, and has not existed for some time, the statements set forth in Mr. Roe's letter and report of June 12 make quite clear, and they are unanimously of the opinion that definite and authoritative steps should be taken in the immediate future to effect a radical improvement on this situation.

In the past, and ever since they have been entrusted with the responsibility of administering the Indian Residential Schools of our Society, our Commission have studiously refrained, even when there was ample provocation, to adopt a different course, from submitting to your Department anything after the nature of an adverse report on the conduct of any of your Indian Agents in the discharge of their duties. From this practice they are even now very reluctant to depart, as they are fully desirous that the relationship of mutual good-will which at present exists between your Department and our Society should not only remain unmolested, but be strengthened and maintained. The attitude, however, of Mr. Indian Agent Arthur...
towards our Peigan School, as set forth by Mr. Roe in his letter and report of June 12, and copies of which were forwarded to you on the 17th ultimo, raises, in their estimation, a question of sufficiently grave importance to warrant a departure on their part from the practice which they have observed hitherto; and, if the statements made by Mr. Roe can, as he affirms and our Commission believe, be substantiated, then we are brought face to face with a situation which, from the standpoint of our Society, is so manifestly inimical to fair play, that even with the best of good-will in the world, we should neither be asked nor expected to tolerate it.

"From the beginning of my career here (February 1922) Mr. Roe writes, 'it was evident to me that, judging by Mr. Arthur's conversations, he had very little use for our school, and that his sympathies were entirely with the R.C. School on this Reserve. All the virtues were centred in the R.C.s and the vices contained in our School'. (Letter June 12, P.1)

Further on he adds:

"Invariably, on Mr. Arthur's visits to this school, he would tell me that the days of the Anglican School were numbered, even going so far as to approximate the time - 5 years - when the School would be defunct. He has not only made this observation to me, but is also priming the Indians on the Reserve with it, and they have come and told me! (Mr. June 12, P.1)

The above statements, so far as they refer to Mr. Arthur's partiality to the Roman Catholic institution, can be supported by Mr. Haynes, our Society's Missionary on the Peigan Reserve and by Nurse Cameron, now on the staff at the Dynevor Hospital, but who, for three months, practically alone, conducted, with great acceptance and benefit to the Peigan Indians, the little Hospital opened by your Department in one of the Peigan Agency buildings.

That Mr. Arthur, or any other Agent of your Department, is at perfect liberty to entertain his own personal opinion of the relative importance of the work which is being done by the Indian Educational Institutions under the supervision of the different religious bodies, our Commission have not the slightest inclination to question; but, when expression is given to these opinions in such a way as to tend to further the efforts of the one he favours and to obstruct those of the one for which he does not entertain so high a regard, they believe that such action is not only, not in conformity with the wishes of your Department, but such as must prove seriously detrimental to the achievement of results worthy of the purpose for which these institutions are operated and maintained."
That Mr. Arthur, as Agent in Charge of the Peigan Agency, has erred in the way just intimated, our Commission have sufficient reason to believe, and they have instructed me to request you to take whatever action you may consider necessary in this important matter.

They have further instructed me to request you to reconsider the action taken by him in placing the children of No Chief in the R.C. School. This matter was brought to the attention of your Department during my last visit, which was on Oct. 26, 1923, when the Superintendent of Indian Education undertook to address a letter to Mr. Arthur in this connexion. The action taken by Mr. Arthur in this matter cannot, so far as they have been able to understand it, be justified, and they are of the opinion that, after you have given it further consideration, you will authorize the transfer of these children from the Roman Catholic to the Church of England School, to which institution it appears to them, they rightly belong.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary M.S.C.C. and Secretary-Treasurer of their Indian & Eskimo Commission.

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of March 26th. (116-1-1) in which you refer (1) a "difficulty which was experienced in maintaining quarantine" at our Society's Peigan School when there was a case of scarlet fever at this institution, and (2) informing me that Mr. Arthur, your Indian Agent on the Peigan Reserve, stated in his report to you that "this difficulty was caused by the very reprehensible attitude of all the female members of the staff".

With reference to the "difficulty" mentioned in section (1) I beg to state that when I visited this School on the 6th of March (quarantine was lifted from the main school building by February 25th, but still remained on the Principal's residence) on my way back from the School at Wabasca, I was informed by the Matron-in-charge and the other lady agents on the staff of what had transpired at the time of Dr. Gillespie's visit on February 9th when the main school building as well as the Principal's residence were placed under quarantine.

The information which I received while it made clear to me that some unpleasantness had arisen between the doctor and the lady agents over the placing of the main school building under quarantine, did not impress me at the time as being of sufficient importance to necessitate any minute investigation of all the causes which conspired to produce the same.

I investigated the situation, however, sufficiently thoroughly to convince myself that a mis-understanding had arisen over the question of posting letters from the school, and as I was informed by the lady agents that no specific instructions...
had been issued by the Doctor on this point, I saw no reason to doubt the veracity of this information, and especially as it was imparted to me by the three lady agents who were in residence at the school at that time.

When I arrived in Winnipeg on March 2nd, I found a letter from Dr. Gillespie (dated Pincher Creek, February 19th) in referring to this matter he writes as follows:

"I was called to see the child of the Principal, Mr. Roe, who was suffering from Scarlet Fever. The date of my first visit was February 9th, 1925. The child with the remaining members of the family were isolated and quarantined in Mr. Roe's residence. As the principal and one or two of the children from the school had been back and forth from the school, and for the protection of the other children in the school and those in the neighborhood of Brocket I placed the school in quarantine as well. I also forbade any mail from leaving the institution.

Immediately after having called the staff together and had explained to them the gravity of the situation and asked for their co-operation in keeping the disease confined to its proper limits, the teacher stalks out and up to the post office where there are three young children. The teacher says in her defense that she did not know that the school was in quarantine. I had to take her word for that but I can't conceive of a thread of truth in her statement."

As Mr. Roe the acting Principal was still under quarantine I sent a copy of Dr. Gillespie's letter to the Matron in charge and requested her to furnish me with a written statement on this subject. In her reply she states as follows:

"On Sunday, February 8th., "Teddy" (the Principal's little boy) was poorly and on Monday the Doctor came. After visiting the cottage (Principal's residence) the Doctor and Mr. Roe came back to the School. Miss Neville (the Girls' Supervisor—a fully trained nurse) and I were called into the office, and told that Teddy had Scarlet Fever, and that no Indians were to come from the Reserve, nor were any of the School children to go to Brocket for a month........... Mail was not mentioned, nor were the staff called together on this occasion. After School Miss Holden (the Teacher) was told, but I do not think for a minute she realized that she could not mail her letter as was her custom, every Monday afternoon.

As Mrs. Grice who was visiting the Roos at the time was allowed to leave by the midnight train—to leave the house where the fever actually was, and endanger people on the train. Miss Holden felt that she would be allowed to post her letter."

"On Wednesday, February 16th, Miss Neville went to speak to Mr. Roe about something, and it was then that the message came that no mail was to go out for a month".

"On Thursday afternoon, February 17th, the Doctor called and asked to speak to the staff. While I was getting Miss Holden and Miss Cheshire, Miss Neville asked him a professional question..."
and he ignored her. Nor did he answer the others when they came in and passed the time of day.

He fired straight at Miss Holden telling her she was big enough and old enough to know better than to break quarantine. She asked if she had broken quarantine, why Mrs. Grice was allowed to leave the same night to travel by train. He said it was a special case.

He did not mention mail, and Miss Cheshire asked him if our mail was stopped for a month. He then forbade any of us to send out any mail for one month.

From the above extracts it appears to me to be quite clear that any "difficulty" which arose was caused in the first instance through a misunderstanding.

With regard to the statement made by your Indian Agent and referred to in section (2) above, viz; that "this difficulty was caused by the very reprehensible attitude of all of the female members of the staff", it appears to me to be equally clear from the information contained in the Head Matron's letter, and quoted above, that the accusation made is not supported by the facts of the case.

The ladies in question may not be altogether blameless, but your representative, before he made his report, should have consulted one or more of them as to what actually happened at the time of the Doctor's visit. Had he done this, and then endeavoured to form an impartial opinion, it is very difficult to believe that his report could have contained the offensive and misleading statement you have quoted.

The accusation, however, which he has made, is quite in keeping with what I have been forced to expect from him from the attitude he has assumed towards the School in question for some time past.

The opinion of our Society with regard to this attitude was set forth in my letter to you dated July 8th, 1924 and this opinion remains unchanged.

I remain, Sir,

Yours very truly,

NEW RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS NEAR COMPLETION ON PEIGAN RESERVE; MEANS EXPENDITURE OF $130,000

Govt. Providing Every Modern Convenience in New Plants

MARVELLOUS PROGRESS IN INDIAN EDUCATION

In fulfillment of its announced policy of providing modern educational facilities for the Indians wards of the government, the Department of Indian Affairs has under construction, and now almost completed, two fine residential schools for the education of the boys and girls of the Peigan reserve.

One school will be administered by the Roman Catholic church, and the other by the Church of England. The former building being located about six miles south east of Bracken near the Canadian border, and the latter about three and a half miles from Bracken near the highway to Fishburn.

Description of Buildings

In general plan the two buildings are similar, but in interior arrangements accommodations have been made to meet the requirements of the respective institutions; there being a number of rooms in each of the Church of England school as residential quarters for the principal and his family.

The main building of each school has 100 feet frontage, 24 feet depth, and is four stories high including the basement, beneath which there is a rear extension of one story, 100 feet by 24 feet, which contains the boiler room, machinery room, laundry, dairy, bath-room, store rooms, etc., rooms in the commodious well-lighted basement of the main building are placed the offices, library, dining-room, boys' and girls' play rooms, lavatories, store rooms and scullery. On the second floor above the entrance hall are the principal's office and school parlor, and also on this floor back of the main entrance is the school chapel, staff room, bedrooms, bathroom and store room.

Upper Stories

The next above the ground floor comprises another class room, boys' and girls' dormitories, washrooms, bathrooms, attached pharmacy, a large well-lighted sewing room with access to balcony, and store rooms, all easily reached from spacious corridors which regularly increase in size.

The top floor is divided in half by a solid wall across the centre and contains boys' and girls' dormitories, well-ventilated dormitories, with sleeping accommodation for 50 children, one bedroom for the principal and one for the girls each with a supervisor's room attached. Two stairways extend from the basement to the top storey and steel fire escapes provide exit from all floors at each end of the main building. Fire-fighting hydrants are also installed at suitable points.

The schools are of frame construction throughout, with brick walls and plastered interior. The foundations are of concrete, extending one foot above grade level, and the brickwork is low for the brick veneering of the building should it ever be deemed necessary.

Interior Conveniences

The most approved modern conveniences are installed throughout each building. A Dunham low pressure steam heating system of the type will provide abundant heat in severest weather, and running hot and cold water will be supplied to each building from large pneumatic storage tanks in the basement, drawn by a powerful pumping plant. Each school will have its own lighting system consisting of a 6 K.W. Lister-Branson portable lighting plant, automatic in operation. Electric bells and fire alarm gongs are provided.

Instruction

The department has allotted a full section of land to each school, and in addition to the ordinary public school courses, the boys will receive training in farming, dairying, care of live stock, and carpentry; and the girls' training will include domestic science and domestic arts. Excellent buildings have been constructed for each school, consisting of a large stock barn with suitable equipment, an implement shed, and poultry house, and other outbuildings are being provided.

The plans of the schools were designed by the department's architect, Mr. J. Murray Orr, R.A., of Ottawa; and Mr. Gardner-Smith is the department's building inspector supervising the erection of the buildings.

The contractor for the Roman Catholic school is Mr. B. D. Scanlan of Medicine Hat, Alta.; Messrs. W. G. Graham and Sons, Ltd., of Moose Jaw, Sask., are the contractors for the Church of England school. These splendid buildings, when fully completed and equipped, will represent an expenditure of approximately $130,000.

No longer can it be said:

"Lo the poor Indian whose untutored soul Sees God in the clouds, or hears Him in the wind."

With the establishment of these modern, commodious buildings, a new era is dawning for the Peigan Indians, and under the efficient administration of the department's chief, Mr. Murray, excellent results may be confidently expected in the uplifting of the native race, and in preparing them ultimately fitting them for the duties and responsibilities of Canadian citizenship.
Bishop Sherman Warmly Welcomed By Indians Of Peigan Reservation; St. Cyprian's Principal Is Ordained

New Anglican Church Leader Spends Busy Sunday at Brocket

RECEIVES MEDICINE PIPE, TOBACCO, POUCH

(Special to The Herald)

BROCKET, May 26—His Lordship the Bishop of Calgary, Rev. Dr. Sherman, M.A., newly elected Anglican bishop of the Diocese of Calgary, accompanied by Ven. Arch-Deacon Timms of the Sarcee Reserve, made his first visit to the Peigan reservation near Pincher Creek, arriving at Brocket on March 19th.

His Lordship was met by Mr. Vivian Lord, principal of the Anglican Indian school, who had been sent out in advance of the reserve, and C. A. Arthur, Indian Agent. On Saturday morning after breakfast at the school head-quarters, the bishop and party proceeded to the new mission church now nearing completion, situated three and a half miles from Brocket. This mission church has been officially named St. Cyprian. Indian residents of the Peigan Reservation, Bishop of Calgary, the Right Rev. Cyprian W. Pinkham, D.D., in recognition of his services in the welfare of the Peigan Indians extending over many years.

Inspecting New School

The bishop and party were received at the school by the school department and building inspector, E. Gardiner, who showed them the progress of the new building following, expression and pleasure was expressed by all at the neatness and comfort and conveniences of the edifice were noted and the bishop was most impressed with its forward policy in providing such splendid facilities for the education of the Peigan boys and girls. His Lordship commented favorably upon the excellent view of the Rockies as seen from the school.

Welcomed by Indians

An interesting feature of the afternoon was the visit paid by the Indians in the parish hall held for the purpose of extending their welcome to the new missionary. Gifts of welcome were delivered in Blackfoot by Chief Phillip and Mrs. Phillip and Men Who Smoke, their remarks being interpreted into English by Father Pollock. In his speeches, Bishop Sherman was presented with a valuable medicine pipe and tobacco pouch. Ven. Arch-Deacon Timms was also the recipient of an Indian pipe and pouch. His Lordship expressed his pleasure in being so kindly welcomed by the Peigan Indians and assured them of the close personal interest he will take in their welfare and advancement.

Ordination Services

On Sunday morning, March 29, the little church alongside the old Victoria Jubilee Bridge, on the banks of the river bottom, was crowded to capacity by Indians. This old church has been used for Anglican services originally built through the generosity of Mr. F. J. Macdonald, late of C. C., and was formally visited by Lord and Lady Aberdeen during the former's term as governor-general of Canada in the early nineteen twenties. Assisting the bishop at the ordination services were Ven. Arch-Deacon Timms, Rev. Mr. Haynes, minister of St. Augustine's church, Lethbridge, and Rev. W. R. Haynes of the Peigan reserve.

Service in Blackfoot

Proceeding to the mission, Rev. Mr. Haynes conducted a service officially in Blackfoot, in which the Indians took part and did much to impress many to observe their familiarity with the prayer book. The prayers were heartily in the responses and prayers and in the singing of hymns. It was a splendid testimony to the labors of Mr. Haynes in his many years of service to the cause of Christianizing the Indians on this reserve.

Bishop's Sermon

His Lordship prefaced his remarks by saying that he felt sure that the service his address would be of the highest value to the Indians. He referred to professor Bishop Pinkham, who had labored so long and faithfully among the Indians, and who had only relinquished the burden through his own request. He knew that their former bishop was respected and beloved by every person present. His Lordship then spoke of Bishop Pinkham's successor to keep the work to successfully inaugurated. He expressed pleasure at seeing so many Indians present and reminded them that the church knows no division or separation, but that all are one people in Christian fellowship. Proceeding, His Lordship referred to the history of the church to the flowing of a great river which had been there for centuries where ever since apostolic times had received many tributaries and in every generation had been strengthened.

Old Landmarks Passing

On all sides the old world was evidently passing away. The great majestic mountains to the west which looked down upon the valley of the river came and go and remind us of the extreme brevity of life. His own call to serve was that of the church and its individual change. The closing of the old mission house was a sign that they were gathered and the moving into the new building was almost a complete change, yet there were indications of change. Turning to the Book of Acts, His Lordship pointed out the present day application. Concluding, he said: "We are gathered here today in the name of our brother. May he ever be a faithful witness for the church and may he bring many to Christ."

Ordination of School Principal

Following the bishop's address an impressive ceremony took place in which the bishop consecrated an interested congregation of Indians and white people. Mr. Vivian Lord, principal of St. Cyprian Indian residence school. He was ordained by His Lordship and Ven. Arch-Deacon Timms and was duly ordained as deacon of the congregation according to the ritual of the Church of England. There was an enthusiastic response to the communion at the morning service in which about fifty Indians and a lesser number of white people took part.

Sir:-

I have the honour to inform you that we are, today, in receipt of a cheque, No. 7619, for $239.12, forwarded to this office by Mr. Indian Agent Arthur, of the Peigan Reserve.

Last June it was arranged that beef purchased from the Department should be paid for at the time it was bought and we were under the impression that Indian agents at Blackfoot, Blood and Peigan Reserves had acquainted the Department with the arrangement. Apparently, in the case of Peigan, this has not been done, and we have today written Mr. Arthur asking him to submit his report.

Trusting that this point may receive your favorable consideration,

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo, with reference to the supplying of beef to the Peigan C. of E. Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that the beef returns from the Peigan Agency, which are received monthly by the Department, showed beef supplied to the Church of England School as per the enclosed statement. The amounts were charged against the grant during the past fiscal year as was done in former fiscal years.

Recently Mr. Agent Arthur forwarded $239.12, which he stated he had received in payment for beef supplied the school for the months of July, August, September, October, November and December, 1923, and January, 1924. As our books showed that the respective amounts had been charged against the grant, cheque No. 7619 was issued and he was instructed to return this amount to you. For your information I enclose a full statement showing the amount charged against the grant during the past fiscal year.

The agent is being instructed that, in future, he should show on his monthly beef returns the amount received from your office in payment of beef supplied the school, in order that the Department may not charge the respective amounts against the grant.

The other agents interested will be given similar instructions in connection with the beef supplied to Church of England Schools.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. T.R.B. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary,
Missionary Society,
Church of England in Canada,
Alexander Ave.,
Winnipeg, MAN.

Dear Mr. Forward:

Per Capita Grants - Residential Schools -
Shingwauk Home - St. Cyprian's

Reference your letter of June 5

The authorized pupilage at the Shingwauk Home is 135. However, in view of the extra dormitory space available at this school, we have been paying up to five super numeraries for this school.

We will recommend to the Deputy Minister that a super numary grant of $44 be paid for the March quarter as requested in your letter.

Ottawa, July 11th, 1947.

Mr. A. McMillan, Indian Agent,
Brocket, Alberta.

The Department finds it necessary to send back
the June quarter return of the St. Cyprian's Residential
School.

From the information contained on the return it
is evident that the pupils were allowed out on holidays
previous to June 30th. On the return, grants should have
been requested for 91 days for each of the pupils who
were in residence during the full quarter.

As you are aware, we allow grant for 62 days
holidays and if pupils were allowed four days holidays
during the June quarter, it means that only 58 days
holidays should be requested when preparing the September
quarter return.

When preparing the September quarter the
principal should request grant for each pupil who was in
residence at the time school closed for holidays for 58
days plus the number of days such pupil is in actual
residence during the period July 1st to September 30th.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Per Capita Grant, 1947
St. Cyprian Indian Residential School
Brocket, Alberta.

According to figures supplied to this office, the Per Capita Grant (exclusive of the recent 17% increase from 1st October) on account of the above school in 1947 was as follows:

| Month | Amount   |
|-------|----------|
| March | $2,625.00|
| June  | $2,625.00|
| Sept. | $2,749.95|
| Dec.  | $2,911.12|
| Total | $10,911.07|

Divided by the Per Capita Grant of $210 (Basic, $165; Special, $15; Emergency, $30) this gives an average pupilage for 1947 of approximately 52.

In a letter dated 13th March, 1948, the Principal points out, however, that from 1st January to 30th June 54 children were in residence and from the opening of the autumn term until 31st December, 1947, 58 children were in residence and he calculates the average pupilage for the year as 55.45.

As I am not familiar with the method you employ in computing the Per Capita Grant for September quarters, it will be appreciated if your figures can be reviewed in the light of the foregoing and this office advised as to how the total of $10,911.07 was determined.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Ven. Henry G. Cook
Superintendent
Ottawa, March 18, 1948.

Dear Archdeacon Cook:

We have your letter of the 17th instant, file Pg-6, with reference to the per capita allowance at the St. Cyprian Residential School.

The authorized pupilage at this school was 50. The average attendance for the quarters ended March 31st and June 30th was 54 but we only allowed the authorized pupilage.

The average for the September quarter was 52.38 and for December 55.45. In regard to the September quarter, we allowed supernumerary grant for 2.38 pupils and in the December quarter, for 5.45 pupils. In other words, we paid the per capita allowance for the full average attendance during those two quarters, although as stated above, the authorized pupilage was only 50.

We have arranged to increase the authorized pupilage at St. Cyprian's to 60 for the fiscal year 1948-49.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Extract from Agent's Letter

Regina
Nov 25th 1889.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 5th instant I beg to enclose under a separate cover three rough sketches, which will give you the dimensions, inside measurements, and general appearance of the Church of England new boarding School building on this Reserve.

The left-hand half of the building is of logs hewn on the inside, and with the exception of the dining room, which he will share with the pupils, will be used by Mr. Bourne and his family as their residence. The roof of this part of the building as well as of the right-hand portion is shingle.

The right-hand portion of the building is all of lumber—rough lumber, and clapboard on the outside; rough lumber and dressed siding on inside, with cement in between the inside and outside walls.

Mr. Bourne.

The Indian Commr.,
Regina.

Indian Affairs. (RG IC, Volume 6560, file 763-5, part 1)

Yours etc,

Sir:

In reply to the above reference Circular, re fire protection. I beg to submit to you my report concerning the C of E School on this Reserve.

I have thoroughly inspected this School with the following results:

All chimneys are of brick, and have been recently cleaned.

Stove pipes are in good repair, and are cleaned once a month.

One well in the School, with a poor supply of water, the Principal informs me that it is impossible to dig this deeper on account of quick sand. I have caused a barrel to be placed beside the well, with orders that it is to be kept full at all times.

Where stove pipes run through the ceilings and walls, thimbles embedded in lime are used, except in two cases, in these I will have thimbles put in at once.

The Indian Commissioner,
Regina.
The following articles are required, there being none available at the Agency or School:

- 24 Grenades.
- 12 Pails.
- 1 Babcock. This last is not absolutely required, but would be of great service in case of fire.

As soon as the above appliances are supplied, I will have the pupils drilled in their use.

I omitted to mention above that the water is drawn from the well by rope and bucket.

I have the honour to be

Sir
